member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase
member.summary: Provides an base class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms controls.
member.remarks:
provides properties to configure the appearance of Measurement Studio .NET Windows Forms controls. You can use , , , and to customize the background and foreground of the control. Use to change the border of the control. You can use to specify if the control draw a focus rectangle when the control has focus. You can change the caption and its background color, font, foreground color, and position with , , , , and respectively.
provides additional members for managing the painting of the control. Use to specify if the control updates when invalidated. suspends the painting of the control until is called. resumes the painting of the control that is suspended by calling . Use and when making many changes to the appearance of the control to minimize distraction to the end-user by preventing flickering and to improve performance. Use to draw the control to a GDI+ drawing surface by passing the appropriate object. The object can represent the drawing surface of an image, the drawing surface of another device such as the printer, or the drawing surface of an area of the screen other than the area in which the component is located.
For more information about the Windows Forms controls, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms .NET Controls.
member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms .NET Controls

This method is called by the public method and the finalizer. invokes the protected Dispose(Boolean) method with the parameter set to . The finalizer invokes with set to .
When the parameter is , this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this references. This method invokes the of each referenced object.
can be called multiple times by other objects. When overriding Dispose(Boolean), be careful not to reference objects that have been previously disposed of in an earlier call to .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.BeginUpdate
member.summary: Suspends the painting of the control until is called.
member.remarks:
When making many changes to the appearance of a control, you can call to temporarily suspend the painting of the control. This results in less distraction to the end-user by preventing flickering when making many changes to the appearance of a control and improves performance. After all updates are made, call to resume drawing of the control. You must call once for each call to .
requires with be granted to the NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms assembly. If the permission is not granted, has no effect.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.EndUpdate
member.summary: Resumes the painting of the control suspended by calling .
member.remarks:
When making many changes to the appearance of a control, you can call to temporarily suspend the painting of the control. This results in less distraction to the end-user by preventing flickering when making many changes to the appearance of a control and improves performance. After all updates are made, call to resume drawing of the control. You must call once for each call to .
requires with be granted to the NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms assembly. If the permission is not granted, has no effect.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.Draw(NationalInstruments.UI.ComponentDrawArgs)
member.summary: Draws the control with the specified .
member.param: A that contains the drawing data.

remarks.para: The in specifies the to use for drawing. The in specifies the bounds in which the control is drawn.

Use to draw the control to a GDI+ drawing surface by passing the appropriate object. The object can represent the drawing surface of an image, the drawing surface of another device such as the printer, or the drawing surface of an area of the screen other than the area in which the component is located. Passing the drawing surface of an image allows the component to be drawn to an image format of your choice. You can query the bounds and size of the control using and , respectively.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates drawing a control to a .png image file in response to the event.
Public Sub ControlBase_Paint(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As PaintEventArgs) Dim imageFileName As String = "ControlImage.png" Using bmp As New Bitmap(baseControl.Width, baseControl.Height) Dim g As Graphics = Graphics.FromImage(bmp) Dim args As New ComponentDrawArgs(g, New Rectangle(0, 0, bmp.Width, bmp.Height))
baseControl.Draw(args) bmp.Save(imageFileName, ImageFormat.Png) End Using Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("file {0} has been saved", imageFileName)) End Sub

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.ToImage
member.summary: Creates an image of the control.
member.returns: An that represents the control.

remarks.para: When a color in the control is set to , the returned image contains transparency information. Due to limitations in the .NET Framework, when you an image and specify as the image format, transparency is lost. Refer to Microsoft KB 318343 for information about GDI+ and GIF files saved using the 8-bpp format. However, you can save an image of the control without losing transparency. Call the or method and specify or as the to save the image with transparency information.

If a control uses 3D styles, such as the , , or controls, and is set to , the resulting image will have a white background instead of a transparent background. If you do not want this behavior, override the Is3D property of the corresponding style property to return .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.ToImage(System.Drawing.Size)
member.summary: Creates an image of the control with a specified size.
member.param: A that specifies the width and height of the exported image.
member.returns: An that represents the control.

remarks.para: When a color in the control is set to , the returned image contains transparency information. Due to limitations in the .NET Framework, when you an image and specify as the image format, transparency is lost. Refer to Microsoft KB 318343 for information about GDI+ and GIF files saved using the 8-bpp format. However, you can save an image of the control without losing transparency. Call the or method and specify or as the to save the image with transparency information.

If a control uses 3D styles, such as the , , or controls, and is set to , the resulting image will have a white background instead of a transparent background. If you do not want this behavior, override the Is3D property of the corresponding style property to return .

member.example:
The following example demonstrates getting an image object from a control, manipulating the image object, and then saving it to a .png file in response to a user pressing Ctrl+S while the control has focus.
Public Sub ControlBase_KeyDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As KeyEventArgs) ' Rotate and save the control when <Ctrl+S> is pressed. If Control.ModifierKeys = Keys.Control AndAlso e.KeyCode = Keys.S Then ' Get the control image, then rotate it 90 degrees. Dim image As Image = baseControl.ToImage(New Size(baseControl.Width, baseControl.Height)) image.RotateFlip(RotateFlipType.Rotate90FlipNone) image.Save("FlippedImage.png", ImageFormat.Png) End If End Sub

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.ToStream(System.IO.Stream,NationalInstruments.UI.ImageType)
member.summary: Writes an image of the control to a stream.
member.param: A to write the image to.
The format of the image.

remarks.para: When the parameter specified is either or and the image is transparent, the stream will include transparency information.

If a control uses 3D styles, such as the , , or controls, and is set to , the resulting image will have a white background instead of a transparent background. If you do not want this behavior, override the Is3D property of the corresponding style property to return .
If the is set to and the specified image does not support transparent colors, such as or , then the transparent region of the control will be saved as a white region.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.ToStream(System.IO.Stream,NationalInstruments.UI.ImageType,System.Drawing.Size)
member.summary: Writes an image of the control to a stream with a specified size.
member.param: A to write the image to.
The format of the image.
A that specifies the width and height of the image that is written to the stream.

remarks.para: When the parameter specified is either or and the image is transparent, the stream will include transparency information.

If a control uses 3D styles, such as the , , or controls, and is set to , the resulting image will have a white background instead of a transparent background. If you do not want this behavior, override the Is3D property of the corresponding style property to return .
If is set to and the specified image does not support transparent colors, such as or , then the transparent region of the control will be saved as a white region.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates writing a control to a object and then saving that stream as a .png image file in response to a user pressing Ctrl + S while the control has focus.
Public Sub ControlBase_KeyDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As KeyEventArgs) ' Save the control from a stream when <Ctrl + S> is pressed. If Control.ModifierKeys = Keys.Control AndAlso e.KeyCode = Keys.S Then Dim imageStream As New FileStream("ImageFromStream.png", FileMode.Create) ' Writes the image of the control to a stream. baseControl.ToStream(imageStream, ImageType.Png, New Size(baseControl.Width, baseControl.Height)) imageStream.Dispose() End If End Sub

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.BeforeDrawCaption
member.summary: Occurs before the caption is drawn.
member.remarks: You can use to participate in the drawing of the . The event occurs before the control begins to draw the caption, but after the has already drawn. Set the property of the event argument to to cancel drawing of the caption. Cancelling the drawing of the caption prevents the caption from being drawn. If you set to , is always raised; however, the event is not raised. You must provide all of the implementation for drawing the caption if is set to .
member.exception: An event handler is added after the object has been disposed.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlBase.AfterDrawCaption
member.summary: Occurs after the caption is drawn.
member.remarks: You can use to participate in the drawing of the caption. The event occurs after the control has completed drawing the caption. You can use this event in conjunction with custom drawing to annotate the caption. If you set the property to in the event arguments of the event, this event is not raised.
member.exception: An event handler is added after the object has been disposed.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.BooleanArray`1
member.summary: Represents the array of Measurement Studio Windows Forms controls for displaying and editing Boolean values.
member.typeparam: The type of the control for which an array is created. The type must derive from , implement and , and specify a default constructor.

remarks.para:
provides the ability to set the data values displayed by the items of the array. You can also use
to set the data values displayed by the array to a sample in a and to display data values of a signal in a . Setting the data values raises the event. You can obtain the data values of the control by calling .
Use to bind the to a data source.

When the property is set to true, the value of all the controls in the array is set to false to ensure that only one value can be set to true at a time. However, the values of the controls are not overwritten when this value is set to false.
remarks.note: Refer to Generics in the .NET Framework for more information about generics.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlArray`1
member.summary: Provides the base class for controls that encapsulate other controls as an array.
member.typeparam: The type of the control for which an array is created. The type must derive from , implement and , and specify a default constructor.

remarks.para: A control can be encapsulated as an array if it meets the constraints of the generic type parameter . uses to create new instances of items in the array. The items must also implement to allow the array to update its appearance and behavior when a property value is changed. itself meets the constraints of the generic type parameter allowing you to create 2D arrays of controls.

You can configure the layout and appearance of the array through the , , and properties. The is cloned to create new instances of items added to the array. The appearance of the dictates the appearance of newly created items of the array.

You can configure the scaling behavior of the array by specifying a fixed number of items in the array or by allowing the array to automatically adjust the number of items in the array based on the number of specified data values using . Use to obtain the number of items in the array.

suspends the painting of the control until is called. resumes the painting of the control that was suspended by calling . When making many changes to the appearance of the control, use and to improve performance and to minimize distraction by preventing flickering.
The control provides the event that is raised when the value of a property changes. The event is raised when the value of a property of an array item changes.
remarks.note: Refer to Generics in the .NET Framework for more information about generics.
If you create two-dimensional arrays of controls, then you must call on the control array after you have finished using it to reclaim memory and perform cleanup.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlArray`1.BeginUpdate
member.summary: Suspends the painting of the control until is called.
member.remarks:
When making many changes to the appearance of a control, you can call to temporarily suspend the painting of the control. Temporarily suspending the painting of the control improves performance and prevents flickering, resulting in less distractions. After all updates are made, call to resume drawing of the control. You must call once for each call to .
requires that with be granted to the NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms assembly. If permission is not granted, has no effect.

member.remarks:
When making many changes to the appearance of a control, you can call to temporarily suspend the painting of the control. Temporarily suspending the painting of the control improves performance and prevents flickering, resulting in less distractions. After all updates are made, call to resume drawing of the control. You must call once for each call to .
requires that with be granted to the NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms assembly. If permission is not granted, has no effect.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ControlArray`1.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new object that is a copy of this instance.
member.returns: A new object that is a copy of this instance.
member.remarks:
creates a new object that is a deep copy of .
A shallow copy creates a new instance of the same type as the original object, and then copies the nonstatic fields of the original object. If the field is a value type, a bit-by-bit copy of the field is performed. If the field is a reference type, the reference is copied but the referred object is not; therefore, the reference in the original object and the reference in the clone point to the same object. In contrast, a deep copy of an object duplicates everything directly or indirectly referenced by the fields in the object.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ComplexGraph
member.summary: Represents the class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms graphs that accept data values.

remarks.para: You can use the collection to include multiple instances on a single graph. With multiple plots, you can plot multiple sets of data in the same plot area. You can determine whether plot colors are assigned by a color generator with the property, and you can change the plot color assignment with the property.

Use to plot the imaginary part against the real part of the or to plot an array of imaginary values against an array of real values. plots imaginary values against real values by appending the values to the existing data.
remarks.note: You need to use to plot . For more information about the complex graph control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls or Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Complex Graph .NET Control Features.

member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Complex Graph .NET Control Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph
member.summary: Provides an base class for all Measurement Studio Windows Forms graph controls.
member.remarks:
is the base class for all graph controls. Use a graph control to visualize data in a plot area.
supports multiple plots on a single graph. Use multiple plots to plot multiple sets of data in the same plot area. occurs when the collection of plots is modified through an add, remove, insert, or clear operation.
You can use to clear data from all of the plots in the graph plot collection.
, , and provide the ability to change the appearance of the plot area. To retrieve the bounds of the plot area, use . raises mouse events for the plot area in the form of , , , and . Custom drawing of the plot area is supported through the and events. occurs before the plot area is drawn. occurs after the plot area is drawn. , and provide a convenient way to draw the plot area image, grid lines, and plot area components, such as plots and cursors, while custom drawing the plot area. Use these events to participate in the drawing of the plot area.
supports interaction. is used to configure the suite of interactions with the graph. Use and to zoom into the plot area around a point or a selection. The event is raised when zooming interactively or programmatically. pans the plot area relative to the existing view. The event is raised when panning interactively or programmatically. can undo the last zoom or pan operation. The event is raised when the zoom or pan is undone interactively or programmatically. reverts all zoom and pan operations to restore the plot area to its initial state. The event is raised when the plot area is reset interactively or programmatically.
The client coordinates of the plot area differ from the actual coordinates to enhance ease of use. You must use the bounds of the plot area in virtual coordinates when passing arguments to , , and . The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0). and convert client coordinates to virtual coordinates. and convert virtual coordinates to client coordinates.
For more information about the graph controls, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls.
member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.ClearData
member.summary: Removes all data from the history of all plots on the graph.

example.code: graph.ClearData()
graph.ClearData();

member.remarks: When you use this method to clear data on the graph, the ranges on the axes are not reset to default range values. If you have zoomed or panned, you can reset the range values with . Otherwise, set the range of the axes to the original values.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.PointToVirtual(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Converts the location of the specified client coordinate to a virtual coordinate with respect to the plot area bounds.
member.param: The in client coordinates to convert.
member.returns: A that represents the converted , , in virtual coordinates.
member.remarks: The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0), with (0.0, 0.0) representing the left-bottom corner of the plot area and (1.0, 1.0) representing the right-top corner of the plot area. You can convert a client coordinate outside the plot area. Use to retrieve the bounds of the plot area in client coordinates.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates converting a point in client coordinates to a point in virtual coordinates.
Dim clientPoint As New Point() Dim bounds As Rectangle = graph.PlotAreaBounds Dim virtualPoint As PointF ' Het the client point for the center of the plot. clientPoint.X = CInt(bounds.Width) \ 2 + bounds.X clientPoint.Y = CInt(bounds.Height) \ 2 + bounds.Y ' PointToVirtual converts a point from client coordinates ' to virtual coordinates. virtualPoint = graph.PointToVirtual(clientPoint)
Debug.WriteLine("PointToVirtual Inputs: clientPoint.X: " & clientPoint.X.ToString() & " clientPoint.Y: " & clientPoint.Y.ToString()) Debug.WriteLine("PointToVirtual Outputs: virtualPoint X: " & virtualPoint.X.ToString() & " virtualPoint.Y: " & virtualPoint.Y.ToString())

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.VirtualToPoint(System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: Converts the location of the specified virtual point to a client coordinate with respect to the plot area bounds.
member.param: The in virtual coordinates to convert.
member.returns: A that represents the converted , , in client coordinates.
member.remarks: The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0) with (0.0, 0.0) representing the left-bottom corner of the plot area and (1.0, 1.0) representing the right-top corner of the plot area. You can convert a virtual coordinate outside the plot area. Use to retrieve the bounds of the plot area in client coordinates.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.RectangleToVirtual(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Converts the size and location of the specified client rectangle to virtual coordinates with respect to the plot area bounds.
member.param: The in client coordinates to convert.
member.returns: A that represent the converted , , in virtual coordinates.
member.remarks: The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0), with (0.0, 0.0) representing the bottom left corner of the plot area and (1.0, 1.0) representing the top right corner of the plot area. You can convert a client rectangle outside the plot area. Use to retrieve the bounds of the plot area in client coordinates.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates converting a rectangle in client coordinates to a rectangle in virtual coordinates.
Dim clientPoint As New Point() Dim clientRect As New Rectangle() Dim virtualRect As New RectangleF()
' RectangleToVirtual takes the device coordinates from the client rectangle and converts ' them to virtual coordinates, which are values from 0.0 to 1.0, where ' (0.0, 0.0) represents the left-bottom corner of the plot area and (1.0, 1.0) ' represents the right-top corner of the plot area. clientRect = New Rectangle(clientPoint.X, clientPoint.Y, graph.Width / 2, graph.Height / 2) virtualRect = graph.RectangleToVirtual(clientRect)
Debug.WriteLine("RectangletoVirtual Inputs: clientRect.X: " & clientRect.X.ToString() & " clientRect.Y: " & clientRect.Y.ToString() & " clientRect.Height: " & clientRect.Height.ToString() & " clientRect.Width: " & clientRect.Width.ToString()) Debug.WriteLine("RectangletoVirtual Outputs: virtualRect X: " & virtualRect.X.ToString() & " PointToVirtual Outputs: virtualRect Y: " & virtualRect.Y.ToString() & " virtualRect.Height: " & clientRect.Height.ToString() & " virtualRect.Width: " & clientRect.Width.ToString())

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.RectangleToVirtual(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Converts the size and location of the specified client rectangle to virtual coordinates with respect to the plot area bounds.
member.param: The in client coordinates to convert.
member.returns: A that represents the converted , , in virtual coordinates.
member.remarks:
The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0), with (0.0, 0.0) representing the bottom left corner of the plot area and (1.0, 1.0) representing the top right corner of the plot area. You can convert a client rectangle outside the plot area. Use to retrieve the bounds of the plot area in client coordinates.
The parameter represents client coordinates and cannot include floating-point values. If the input includes floating-point values, the values are truncated before the virtual coordinates are calculated and returned.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.VirtualToRectangle(System.Drawing.RectangleF)

member.returns: A that represents the converted , , in client coordinates.
member.remarks: The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0) with (0.0, 0.0) representing the left-bottom corner of the plot area and (1.0, 1.0) representing the right-top corner of the plot area. You can convert a virtual rectangle outside the plot area. Use to retrieve the bounds of the plot area in client coordinates.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.ZoomAroundPoint(System.Single)
member.summary: Zooms around the center of the plot area using the specified zoom factor.
member.param: The factor used to perform the zoom.

exception.para: The is less than or equal to 0.0.

member.remarks:
A value less than 1.0 indicates a zoom out, and a value greater than 1.0 indicates a zoom in. For example, a value of 0.8 zooms out by 80%, and a value of 1.5 zooms in by 150%. If is set to 1.0, the plot area is not zoomed because a value of 1.0 zooms by 100% of the current view.
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about zooming interactively.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming in around the center of the plot on a object area by a factor of 150%.
' The percentage to zoom by - in this case 150%. Dim zoomFactor As Single = 1.5F
' When you only specify a zoom factor, the ' zoom is centered around the center of the graph. graph.ZoomAroundPoint(zoomFactor)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.ZoomAroundPoint(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Zooms around the specified x and y coordinates with the specified zoom factor.
member.param: The percentage to zoom by.
The horizontal position of the point to zoom around in virtual coordinates.
The vertical position of the point to zoom around in virtual coordinates.

exception.para: The is less than or equal to 0.0.

remarks.para: A value less than 1.0 indicates a zoom out, and a value greater than 1.0 indicates a zoom in. For example, a value of 0.8 zooms out by 80%, and a value of 1.5 zooms in by 150%. If is set to 1.0, the plot area is not zoomed because a value of 1.0 zooms by 100% of the current view.

The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0) with (0.0, 0.0) representing the bottom-left corner of the plot area, and (1.0, 1.0) representing the top-right corner of the plot area. Use to convert client coordinates to virtual coordinates of the plot area.
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about zooming interactively.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming in by a factor of 125% around a point on a object obtained from handling the event.
Public Sub Graph_PlotAreaMouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim virtualPoint As PointF Dim zoomFactor As Single = 1.25F
' Only zoom in when the left mouse button is clicked. If e.Button = MouseButtons.Left Then ' get the virtual position of the mouse click virtualPoint = graph.PointToVirtual(e.Location) graph.ZoomAroundPoint(zoomFactor, virtualPoint.X, virtualPoint.Y) End If End Sub

The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0) with (0.0, 0.0) representing the bottom-left corner of the plot area, and (1.0, 1.0) representing the top-right corner of the plot area. Use to convert client coordinates to virtual coordinates of the plot area.
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .

member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming in by a factor of 125% around a point on a object obtained from handling the event.
Public Sub Graph_PlotAreaMouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim virtualPoint As PointF Dim zoomFactor As Single = 1.25F
' Only zoom in when the left mouse button is clicked. If e.Button = MouseButtons.Left Then ' get the virtual position of the mouse click virtualPoint = graph.PointToVirtual(e.Location) graph.ZoomAroundPoint(zoomFactor, virtualPoint) End If End Sub

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.ZoomXY(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Zooms to the region of the plot area specified by the x location, y location, width, and height.
member.param: The horizontal position in virtual coordinates of the bottom-left corner of the region of the plot area to zoom.
The vertical position in virtual coordinates of the bottom-left corner of the region of the plot area to zoom.
The width of the region of the plot area to zoom, in virtual coordinates.
The height of the region of the plot area to zoom, in virtual coordinates.

remarks.para: The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0) with (0.0, 0.0) representing the bottom-left corner of the plot area and (1.0, 1.0) representing the top-right corner of the plot area. Use to convert client coordinates to virtual coordinates of the plot area.
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about zooming interactively.
remarks.note: This method may not zoom the graph to the precise floating-point coordinates specified by the parameters due to rounding that occurs when mapping the virtual coordinates to the client coordinates.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming in on a object to a particular region specified by the x location, y location, height, and width of a rectangle.
Dim virtualRect As New RectangleF()
' Zoom in on a rectangle that begins 25% from the x and y ' origins and continues for the next 50% of the plot area. virtualRect.Y = 0.25F virtualRect.X = 0.25F virtualRect.Height = 0.5F virtualRect.Width = 0.5F
graph.ZoomXY(virtualRect.X, virtualRect.Y, virtualRect.Width, virtualRect.Height)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.ZoomXY(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Zooms to the region of the plot area specified by the rectangle.
member.param: The that specifies the region of the plot area to zoom, in virtual coordinates.

remarks.para: The virtual coordinates of the plot area are defined from (0.0, 0.0) to (1.0, 1.0) with (0.0, 0.0) representing the bottom-left corner of the plot area and (1.0, 1.0) representing the top-right corner of the plot area. Use to convert client coordinates to virtual coordinates of the plot area.
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about zooming interactively.
remarks.note: This method may not zoom the graph to the precise floating-point coordinates specified by the parameters due to rounding that occurs when mapping the virtual coordinates to the client coordinates.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming in on a object to a particular region specified by a rectangle 150 pixels high and wide.
' The the bounds of the plot area - in client coordinates. Dim bounds As Rectangle = graph.PlotAreaBounds Dim clientRect As New Rectangle() Dim virtualRect As RectangleF
' Create a client rectangle. Top left of the rectangle is at the ' center of the plot, and it is 150 pixels high and wide. clientRect.Y = bounds.Height \ 2 + bounds.Y clientRect.X = bounds.Width \ 2 + bounds.X clientRect.Height = 150 clientRect.Width = 150
' RectangleToVirtual converts a rectangle from client coordinates ' to virtual coordinates, which are required by ZoomXY. virtualRect = graph.RectangleToVirtual(clientRect) graph.ZoomXY(virtualRect)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.PanXY(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Pans the plot area according to the specified horizontal and vertical factors.
member.param: The horizontal factor.
The vertical factor.
member.remarks:
If you set to 0.0, the plot area is not panned horizontally. If you set to 0.0, the plot area is not panned vertically.
An of 1.0 pans the plot area to the right so that the right edge of the plot area becomes the left edge of the plot area. An of -1.0 pans the plot area to the left so that the left edge of the plot area becomes the right edge of the plot area.
A of 1.0 pans the plot area to the top so that the top edge of the plot area becomes the bottom edge of the plot area. A of -1.0 pans the plot area to the bottom so that the bottom edge of the plot area becomes the top edge of the plot area.
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about panning interactively.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates panning 20% of the plot area to the right and 10% of the plot area upwards.
' Positive pan values pan from right to left and top to bottom. ' Negative pan values pan from left to right and bottom to top. ' The pan values are in virtual coordinates - 0 does not pan, 1 ' pans an entire plot area. graph.PanXY(0.2F, 0.1F)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.UndoZoomPan
member.summary: Reverts the last zoom or pan operation.
member.remarks:
You can undo each zoom and pan operation. To undo only the last operation, use . To undo all operations, use .
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of when the last interactive action is a zoom operation.
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about reverting the last zoom or pan operation interactively.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.ResetZoomPan
member.summary: Reverts all zoom and pan operations to restore the plot area to its initial state.
member.remarks:
You can undo each zoom and pan operation. To undo only the last operation, use . To undo all operations, use .
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of when the first interactive action is a zoom operation.
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about reverting all zoom and pan operations interactively.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.DrawPlotAreaImage(NationalInstruments.UI.ComponentDrawArgs)
member.summary: Draws the background image of the plot area.
member.param: A that contains the drawing data.
member.remarks: provides an easy way to draw the background image of the plot area while custom drawing the plot area. To custom draw the plot area, attach an event handler to the or events. Use the value to draw the image.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates drawing the plot area image of a object to a .png image file in response to the event.
Public Sub Graph_AfterDrawPlotArea(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As AfterDrawEventArgs) Dim imageFileName As String = "PlotAreaImage.png" Using bmp As New Bitmap(graph.PlotAreaBounds.Width, graph.PlotAreaBounds.Height) Dim g As Graphics = Graphics.FromImage(bmp) Dim args As New ComponentDrawArgs(g, New Rectangle(0, 0, bmp.Width, bmp.Height))
graph.DrawPlotAreaImage(args) bmp.Save(imageFileName, ImageFormat.Png) End Using Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("file {0} has been saved", imageFileName)) End Sub

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.DrawGridLines(NationalInstruments.UI.ComponentDrawArgs)
member.summary: Draws the grid lines in the plot area of the graph.
member.param: A that contains the drawing data.
member.remarks: provides an easy way to draw the grid lines while custom drawing the plot area. To custom draw the plot area, attach an event handler to or events. The grid lines are drawn as specified by the major, minor, and custom divisions of the axes.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates drawing the origin lines of a object to a .png image file in response to the event.
Public Sub Graph_AfterDrawPlotArea(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As AfterDrawEventArgs) Dim imageFileName As String = "GridLinesImage.png" Using bmp As New Bitmap(graph.PlotAreaBounds.Width, graph.PlotAreaBounds.Height) Dim g As Graphics = Graphics.FromImage(bmp) Dim args As New ComponentDrawArgs(g, New Rectangle(0, 0, bmp.Width, bmp.Height))
graph.DrawGridLines(args) bmp.Save(imageFileName, ImageFormat.Png) End Using Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("file {0} has been saved", imageFileName)) End Sub

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.InteractionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the user interactions that are supported by the graph.
member.value: A that indicates which user interactions are supported by the graph. The default value is a bitwise combination of , , , , , and .
member.remarks:
For detailed information about graph interactions, refer to Interacting with Measurement Studio Windows Forms .NET Graph Controls.
Set to to enable interaction. If is , the property has no effect regardless of its value. The control must have focus to enable interaction with the use of modifier keys.
Use to enable user interactions without the use of modifier keys.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.InteractionModeDefault
member.summary: Gets or sets the user interaction that is enabled on the graph without the use of a modifier key.
member.value: A that represents the user interaction that is enabled on the graph without the use of a modifier key. The default value is .
member.exception: The value is not an value.
member.remarks:
determines the default interaction of the graph. Unlike , the user is not required to press any modifier keys to interact with the graph when is set to a value other than . For example, if is set to , the user is not required to press the Shift key to zoom with a selection rectangle in the plot area of the graph.
The value of is independent of the value of . For example, can be set to to allow users to zoom with a selection rectangle while can be set to a bitwise combination of and to allow panning in the horizontal and vertical directions.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.SelectionStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the style with which a selection is drawn in the graph.
member.value: A that specifies how a selection is drawn in the graph. The default value is .
member.remarks:
While zooming interactively, the selection style is applied to the selection drawn in the plot area when selecting a rectangle to zoom to.
requires with be granted to the NationalInstruments.UI assembly to allow the operating system setting to be read from the registry. If the security permission is not granted or if the operating system cannot be retrieved, the defaults to on Windows XP or later, and to on Windows 2000 or earlier.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.SelectionColor

member.value: A that represents the color of a selection in the graph. The default value is with an alpha value of 64.
member.remarks: While zooming interactively, the selection color is applied to the selection drawn in the plot area when selecting a rectangle to zoom to.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.ZoomFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the factor to use to zoom around a point when zooming interactively.
member.value: The factor to use to zoom around a point when zooming interactively. The default value is 2.0.
member.remarks:
A value less than 1.0 indicates a zoom out, whereas a value greater than 1.0 indicates a zoom in. For example, a value of 0.8 zooms out by 80% and value of 1.5 zooms in by 150%. If the value is set to 1.0, the plot area is not zoomed because a value of 1.0 zooms by 100% of the current view.
To zoom around a point in the plot area, you must set to a value that includes .

exception.para: The value is less than or equal to 0.0.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.BeforeDrawPlotArea
member.summary: Occurs before the plot area is drawn.
member.remarks: Use to participate in the drawing of the plot area. The event occurs before the graph begins to draw the , but after the has already drawn. Set the property of the event argument to to cancel drawing of the plot area. Cancelling the drawing of the plot area prevents the plot area image, grid lines, and its contents, such as plots and cursors, from being drawn. and provide the ability to draw the plot area image and grid lines, respectively. draws the contents of the plot area, such as plots and cursors. If you set to , is always raised; however, the event is not raised. You must provide all of the implementation for drawing the plot area if is set to .
member.exception: An event handler is added after the object has been disposed.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Graph.AfterDrawPlotArea
member.summary: Occurs after the plot area is drawn.
member.remarks: Use to participate in the drawing of the plot area. The event occurs after the graph has completed drawing the plot area and its contents, such as plots and cursors. Use this event in conjunction with custom drawing to annotate the plot area. If you set the property to in the event arguments of the event, this event is not raised.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ComplexGraph.ZoomAroundPoint(System.Single,NationalInstruments.UI.ComplexPlot,NationalInstruments.ComplexDouble)
member.summary: Zooms around the specified data point with the specified zoom factor and reference plot.
member.param: The percentage to zoom by.
A to use as the context for .
The data point, represented as a , to zoom around.

exception.para: is less than or equal to 0.0.

member.remarks:
A value less than 1.0 indicates a zoom out, and a value greater than 1.0 indicates a zoom in. For example, a value of 0.8 zooms out by 80%, and a value of 1.5 zooms in by 150%. If is set to 1.0, the plot area is not zoomed because a value of 1.0 zooms by 100% of the view.
The imaginary part and real part of are mapped to client coordinates using the and properties of . The and act as the scale for mapping. The client coordinates are mapped to virtual coordinates using . Use the virtual coordinates to call .
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about zooming interactively.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming in by 125% around a point on a object. You determine the point to zoom around by handling the event.
Public Sub ComplexGraph_PlotAreaMouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim zoomFactor As Single = 1.25F Dim dataPoint As New ComplexDouble() Dim virtualPoint As PointF Dim rangeMin As Double, rangeMax As Double
' only zoom in when the left mouse button is clicked If e.Button = MouseButtons.Left Then ' get the virtual position of the mouse click so that we can ' map to data coordinates on the graph. virtualPoint = cxGraph.PointToVirtual(e.Location)
rangeMin = cxGraph.XAxes(0).Range.Minimum rangeMax = cxGraph.XAxes(0).Range.Maximum dataPoint.Real = (rangeMax - rangeMin) * virtualPoint.X + rangeMin
rangeMin = cxGraph.YAxes(0).Range.Minimum rangeMax = cxGraph.YAxes(0).Range.Maximum dataPoint.Imaginary = (rangeMax - rangeMin) * virtualPoint.Y + rangeMin
cxGraph.ZoomAroundPoint(zoomFactor, cxGraph.Plots(0), dataPoint) End If End Sub

remarks.para: The imaginary part and real part of are mapped to client coordinates using the and properties of . The and act as the scale for mapping. The client coordinates are mapped to virtual coordinates using . Use the virtual coordinates to call .
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about zooming interactively.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming to a specifically sized rectangle on a plot.
Dim width As Double = 3 Dim height As Double = 2 Dim corner As New ComplexDouble(-2.0, -3.0)
cxGraph.ZoomXY(cxGraph.Plots(0), corner, width, height)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ComplexGraph.HitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a that specifies where on the control the specified point is located.
member.param: The horizontal location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
The vertical location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
member.returns: A that specifies where on the control the and coordinate is located.
member.remarks:
When hit-testing a coordinate inside the plot area of the graph, respects the z-order of objects within the plot area. If a cursor, plot, and annotation overlap at a particular coordinate, tests for cursor, plot, and annotation in that order.
If indicates an object exists, you can use , , and to obtain a reference to the object.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates using the method to determine where a user clicked on a object.
Public Sub ComplexGraph_MouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim plot As ComplexPlot Dim index As Integer Dim plotData As ComplexDouble Dim hitTestRegion As ComplexGraphHitTestInfo Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))
hitTestRegion = cxGraph.HitTest(e.X, e.Y) Select Case hitTestRegion Case ComplexGraphHitTestInfo.Annotation Dim annot As ComplexPointAnnotation = TryCast(cxGraph.GetAnnotationAt(e.X, e.Y), ComplexPointAnnotation) annot.ShapeFillColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Annotation selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Annotation real position: {0}, annotation imaginary position {1}", annot.Position.Real.ToString(), annot.Position.Imaginary.ToString())) Exit Select Case ComplexGraphHitTestInfo.Cursor Dim cursor As ComplexCursor = cxGraph.GetCursorAt(e.X, e.Y) cursor.Color = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Cursor selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Cursor real position: {0}, cursor imaginary position: {1}", cursor.Position.Real.ToString(), cursor.Position.Imaginary.ToString())) Exit Select Case ComplexGraphHitTestInfo.ErrorBand Dim errData As ComplexDouble Dim realErrString As String, imgErrString As String
plot = cxGraph.GetErrorBandAt(e.X, e.Y, errData, index) plot.LineColor = randomColor plotData = plot.GetDataPoint(index)
If errData.Real > plotData.Real Then realErrString = "upper bound is " & errData.Real.ToString(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture) ElseIf errData.Real < plotData.Real Then realErrString = "lower bound is " & errData.Real.ToString(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture) Else realErrString = "is not set" End If
If errData.Imaginary > plotData.Imaginary Then imgErrString = "upper bound is " & errData.Imaginary.ToString(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture) & "i" ElseIf errData.Imaginary < plotData.Imaginary Then imgErrString = "lower bound is " & errData.Imaginary.ToString(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture) & "i" Else imgErrString = "is not set" End If
Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("The real error data {0}{1}The imaginary error data {2}", realErrString, Environment.NewLine, imgErrString)) Exit Select Case ComplexGraphHitTestInfo.Plot plot = cxGraph.GetPlotAt(e.X, e.Y, plotData, index) plot.LineColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Data point {0} is located at {1} + {2}i", index, plotData.Real, plotData.Imaginary)) Exit Select Case ComplexGraphHitTestInfo.PlotArea Debug.WriteLine("Plot area was clicked") Exit Select Case ComplexGraphHitTestInfo.XAxis Dim xAxis As ComplexXAxis = cxGraph.GetXAxisAt(e.X, e.Y) xAxis.CaptionBackColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Real axis Selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Real Axis range minimum: {0}, real axis range maximum: {1}", xAxis.Range.Minimum.ToString(), xAxis.Range.Maximum.ToString())) Exit Select Case ComplexGraphHitTestInfo.YAxis Dim yAxis As ComplexYAxis = cxGraph.GetYAxisAt(e.X, e.Y) yAxis.CaptionBackColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Imaginary Selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Imaginary axis range minimum: {0}, Imaginary axis range maximum: {1}", yAxis.Range.Minimum.ToString(), yAxis.Range.Maximum.ToString())) Exit Select Case ComplexGraphHitTestInfo.None Debug.WriteLine("Unknown graph area clicked") Exit Select End Select End Sub

Public Sub ComplexGraph_PlotAreaMouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))

member.example:
The following example demonstrates determining which annotation a user clicked on by calling the method in response to the event. For another example of , refer to .
Public Sub ComplexGraph_PlotAreaMouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))
Dim annot As ComplexPointAnnotation = DirectCast(cxGraph.GetAnnotationAt(e.X, e.Y), ComplexPointAnnotation)
If annot IsNot Nothing Then annot.ShapeFillColor = randomColor annot.ShapeLineColor = randomColor annot.ArrowColor = randomColor Else Debug.WriteLine("There was no annotation at the selected location") End If End Sub
member.remarks:
You can pass the and coordinates from the event argument of the , , , or events as the and parameters.
The arrow of the annotation is not used to determine if an annotation is located at the specified coordinates.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ComplexGraph.DrawOriginLines(NationalInstruments.UI.ComponentDrawArgs)
member.summary: Draws the origin lines in the plot area of the complex graph.
member.param: A that contains the drawing data.
member.remarks: provides an easy way to draw the origin lines while custom drawing the plot area. To custom draw the plot area, attach an event handler to or events.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates drawing the origin lines of a object to a .png image file in response to the event.
Public Sub ComplexGraph_AfterDrawPlotArea(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As AfterDrawEventArgs) Dim imageFileName As String = "ComplexGraphOriginLinesImage.png" Using bmp As New Bitmap(cxGraph.PlotAreaBounds.Width, cxGraph.PlotAreaBounds.Height) Dim g As Graphics = Graphics.FromImage(bmp) Dim args As New ComponentDrawArgs(g, New Rectangle(0, 0, bmp.Width, bmp.Height))
cxGraph.DrawOriginLines(args) bmp.Save(imageFileName, ImageFormat.Png) End Using Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("file {0} has been saved", imageFileName)) End Sub

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ComplexGraph.PlotLineColorGenerator
member.summary: Gets or sets the that assigns different colors to plots.
member.value: The that assigns different colors to plots. The default value is .
member.remarks:
At design time, when you add, delete, or move a plot up and down, the colors are reassigned according to the order in which they are specified in the color set. At run time, the color of the plot depends on its index in the plot collection when you add the plot to the collection. If you delete a plot at run time, the color of the other plots does not change.
When this property changes, the event is raised, and colors are assigned to all plots if is .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ComplexGraph.UseColorGenerator
member.summary: Gets or sets whether is enabled or disabled.
member.value: to enable ; otherwise, . The default value is . At design time, this property is set to by a custom control designer for ease of use.
member.remarks: When this property is set to , plots are assigned different colors by the property; otherwise, the plots default to , unless you have explicitly set the colors. determines whether to draw the plot with auto-generated color or with a color you assign.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ComplexGraph.InteractionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the user interactions that are supported by the graph.
member.value: A that indicates which user interactions are supported by the graph. The default value is a bitwise combination of , , , , , and .

remarks.para: Set to to enable interaction. If is , the property has no effect regardless of its value. The control must have focus to enable interaction with the use of modifier keys.
Use to enable user interactions without the use of modifier keys.
For more information about graph interactions, refer to Interacting with Measurement Studio Windows Forms .NET Graph Controls.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ComplexGraph.InteractionModeDefault
member.summary: Gets or sets the user interaction that is enabled on the graph without the use of a modifier key.
member.value: The that represents the user interaction that is enabled on the graph by default. The default value is .
member.remarks:
determines the default interaction of the graph. Unlike , the user is not required to press any modifier keys to interact with the graph when is set to a value other than . For example, if is set to , the user is not required to press the Shift key to zoom with a selection rectangle in the plot area of the graph.
The value of is independent of the value of . For example, can be set to to allow users to zoom with a selection rectangle while can be set to a bitwise combination of and to allow panning in the horizontal and vertical directions.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph
member.summary: Represents the class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms graphs that accept data.

remarks.para: A data type represents a set of digital states that are grouped by samples or signals.

You can use the collection to include multiple instances on a single graph. With multiple plots, you can plot multiple sets of data in the same plot area. Use to plot a waveform and to plot an array of data.
Use to control the height in pixels of the digital plots. Use to specify the amount of space in pixels between signal plots and use to specify the distance in pixels between waveform plots.

You can enable or disable the mode of the horizontal or vertical scroll bar with and , respectively. Use to place the horizontal scroll bar at the top or bottom of the plot area. Use to place the vertical scroll bar to the left or right of the plot area. Use to customize the appearance of the scroll bar.
Use and to configure the digital x and y axes.
You can use to bind the graph to a data source.
remarks.note: For more information about the digital waveform graph control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls or Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Digital Waveform Graph .NET Control Features.

member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Digital Waveform Graph .NET Control Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.GetWaveforms
member.summary: Returns a array containing references.
member.returns: A array containing references.
member.remarks: The digital waveforms returned are referenced and not copied; therefore, if a changes, the updates to reflect the new values.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates getting all the objects associated with a object and printing the states of each waveform to debug output.
Dim waves As DigitalWaveform()
waves = digiGraph.GetWaveforms()
For Each wave As DigitalWaveform In waves Debug.WriteLine(wave.ChannelName + ": ") For Each signal As DigitalWaveformSignal In wave.Signals Dim i As Integer = 0 Debug.Write(vbTab + signal.Name & ": ") For Each state As DigitalState In signal.States If (i Mod 10) <> 0 Then Debug.Write(state.ToString() & " ") Else Debug.Write(Environment.NewLine & vbTab & vbTab & state.ToString() & " ") End If i += 1 Next Debug.Write(Environment.NewLine) Next Next

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.ExpandSignals
member.summary: Expands all digital signals on each digital waveform plot.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.CollapseSignals
member.summary: Collapses all digital signals on each digital waveform plot.

example.code: digiGraph.CollapseSignals()
digiGraph.CollapseSignals();

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.HitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a that specifies where on the control the specified point is located.
member.param: The horizontal location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
The vertical location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
member.returns: A that specifies where on the control the and coordinate is located.
member.remarks:
If indicates an object exists, you can use and
to obtain a reference to the object.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates using the method to determine where a user clicked on a object.
Public Sub DigitalGraph_MouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim hitTestRegion As DigitalWaveformGraphHitTestInfo Dim waveformIndex As Integer, sampleIndex As Integer, signalIndex As Integer Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))
hitTestRegion = digiGraph.HitTest(e.X, e.Y)
Select Case hitTestRegion Case DigitalWaveformGraphHitTestInfo.HorizontalScrollBar Debug.WriteLine("Horizontal scrollbar selected") Exit Select Case DigitalWaveformGraphHitTestInfo.PlotArea Debug.WriteLine("Plot area selected") Exit Select Case DigitalWaveformGraphHitTestInfo.SignalPlot Dim signalPlot As DigitalSignalPlot Dim theState As DigitalState
signalPlot = digiGraph.GetSignalPlotAt(e.X, e.Y, theState, waveformIndex, sampleIndex, signalIndex) signalPlot.LineColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Signal plot selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Sample {0} in signal {1} of waveform {2} has state {3}", sampleIndex, signalIndex, waveformIndex, theState.ToString())) Exit Select Case DigitalWaveformGraphHitTestInfo.VerticalScrollBar Debug.WriteLine("Vertical scrollbar selected") Exit Select Case DigitalWaveformGraphHitTestInfo.WaveformPlot Dim sample As DigitalWaveformSample = Nothing Dim plot As DigitalWaveformPlot Dim states As New List(Of String)(10)
plot = digiGraph.GetWaveformPlotAt(e.X, e.Y, sample, waveformIndex, sampleIndex) plot.LineColor = randomColor For Each state As DigitalState In sample.States states.Add(state.ToString()) Next Debug.WriteLine("Waveform plot selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Waveform {0}'s sample number {1} has states {2}", waveformIndex, sampleIndex, String.Join(" ", states.ToArray()))) Exit Select Case DigitalWaveformGraphHitTestInfo.XAxis digiGraph.XAxis.CaptionBackColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("XAxis selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("X Axis range minimum is {0}, XAxis range maximum is {1}", digiGraph.XAxis.Range.Minimum, digiGraph.XAxis.Range.Maximum)) Exit Select Case DigitalWaveformGraphHitTestInfo.YAxis Debug.WriteLine("YAxis selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("The major divisions grid is {0}visible{1}The minor divisions grid is {2}visible", If(digiGraph.YAxis.MajorGridVisible, "", "not "), Environment.NewLine, If(digiGraph.YAxis.MinorGridVisible, "", "not "))) Exit Select End Select End Sub

member.summary: Gets the digital signal plot at the specified location.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the location, in client coordinates, to search for a signal plot.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by the and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: to release both managed and unmanaged resources; to release only unmanaged resources.
member.remarks:
This method is called by the public method and the finalizer. invokes the protected Dispose(Boolean) method with the parameter set to . The finalizer invokes with set to .
When the parameter is , this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this references. This method invokes the of each referenced object.
can be called multiple times by other objects. When overriding Dispose(Boolean), be careful not to reference objects that have been previously disposed of in an earlier call to .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.PlotWaveform(NationalInstruments.DigitalWaveform)
member.summary: Plots a .
member.param: The to plot.
member.remarks:
does not copy the when it is plotted. You improve plot performance, especially when dealing with large digital waveforms, by not copying the . In this case, the updates when the changes.
The default on the digital x-axis is . If you zoom or pan to an area and then plot new data, you might not see any data in the plot area. To view the data, consider calling or set the of the digital x-axis to the original values.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates plotting a digital waveform to a object.
Dim wave As DigitalWaveform = Nothing
' Get some DigitalWaveform data. GenerateRandomDigitalWaveformData(wave) digiGraph.PlotWaveform(wave)
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Digital Waveform Graph .NET Control Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.PlotWaveform(NationalInstruments.DigitalWaveform,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Plots a with the choice to copy the digital waveform.
member.param: The to plot.
Whether to copy the .

remarks.para: Setting to copies the when it is plotted. By copying the , plotted data remains constant when changes are made to the . Copying large digital waveforms decreases plotting performance.
Setting to does not copy the when it is plotted. You improve plot performance, especially when dealing with large digital waveforms, by not copying the . In this case, updates when the changes.
remarks.note: The deafult on the digital x-axis is . If you zoom or pan to an area and then plot new data, you might not see any data in the plot area. Consider calling or setting of the digital x-axis to view the data in the plot area.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates plotting a digital waveform to a object and electing to create a copy of the object for the purpose of plotting.
Dim wave As DigitalWaveform = Nothing
' Get some DigitalWaveform data. GenerateRandomDigitalWaveformData(wave) 'Passing value of true copies the wave array when plotted. digiGraph.PlotWaveform(wave, True)
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Digital Waveform Graph .NET Control Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.PlotWaveforms(NationalInstruments.DigitalWaveform[])
member.summary: Plots a array.
member.param: The array to plot.
member.remarks:
does not copy the array when it is plotted. You improve plot performance, especially when dealing with large digital waveforms, by not copying the array. In this case, the updates when the array changes.
The deafult on the digital x-axis is . If you zoom or pan to an area and then plot new data, you might not see any data in the plot area. Consider calling or setting of the digital x-axis to view the data in the plot area.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates plotting a array to a object.
Dim waves As DigitalWaveform() = Nothing
' Get some DigitalWaveform data. GenerateRandomDigitalWaveformData(waves) digiGraph.PlotWaveforms(waves)
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Digital Waveform Graph .NET Control Features

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.DigitalWaveformGraph.InteractionModeDefault
member.summary: Gets or sets the user interaction that is enabled on the graph without the use of a modifier key.
member.value: A that represents the user interaction that is enabled on the graph without the use of a modifier key. The default value is .
member.remarks:
determines the default interaction of the graph. Unlike , the user is not required to press any modifier keys to interact with the graph when is set to a value other than . For example, if is set to , the user is not required to press the Shift key to zoom with a selection rectangle in the plot area of the graph.
The value of is independent of the value of . For example, can be set to to allow users to zoom with a selection rectangle while can be set to a bitwise combination of and to allow panning in the horizontal and vertical directions.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Gauge
member.summary: Represents a Measurement Studio Windows Forms gauge control to display numeric values.
member.remarks:
Typically, you use a as an indicator. You can use , , and to change the appearance of the .
The default value of has been changed to give the control a more gauge-like appearance. The default value of is .
For more information about the gauge control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Controls.
member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Controls
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Control Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.RadialNumericPointer
member.summary: Provides an base class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms numeric pointers that display a numeric value in a radial scale.
member.remarks:
is the base class for numeric pointer controls that display a numeric value in a radial scale.
The supports interaction. Use to configure the suite of interactions provided by the control. Use to allow the pointer to be dragged. Use to snap the property to the mouse cursor. You can also change interactively using the up, down, left, and right arrow keys on the keyboard and by scrolling the mouse wheel.
Use to customize the color of the radial area containing the pointer. Specify the arc in which the scale is drawn with . Use to place divisions representing the minimum and maximum of the scale at different angles.
determines the portion of the radial numeric pointer at a specified x and y location.
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Control Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.NumericPointer
member.summary: Provides an base class for all Measurement Studio Windows Forms controls that display a numeric value with a pointer and a scale.
member.remarks:
is the base class for all numeric pointer controls that display a numeric value with a pointer and a scale. Numeric pointer controls accept and display a numeric value, and they enable development of applications that represent scientific instruments with respect to appearance.
The numeric pointer controls have a single pointer and single scale. The pointer indicates the value of . Customize the appearance of the pointer through the property, and enhance the appearance of the control by setting to .
The scale related properties are exposed by to facilitate their access. determines the minimum and maximum values of the scale. Use the property to automatically calculate the location of tick marks. Customize the appearance of tick marks and labels with the and properties. You can also change the format of the labels through these properties. Use to place a division at any value with customized text for the label. Change the scale to logarithmic by changing and setting .
Use the property to change by discrete intervals or continuously within .
The control raises the event before is changed and event after has changed. Cancel the event to prevent from changing. The property of the event argument is set based on how the change was affected.
Use and to move the pointer to the previous and next values programmatically.
The property is bindable to a data source, such as DataSocket.
You can also connect to the control in such a way that changing the value on one control will automatically update the value of the other. Connecting to the control allows more precise control over the value of the numeric pointer control. To connect the , set the property on the to a reference.
For more information about the numeric pointer control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Controls or Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Control Features.
member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Controls
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Control Features

member.summary: Moves the pointer to the previous value as specified by the .
member.returns: if the pointer moved to the previous value.
member.remarks:
The pointer is moved to the previous value as long as the previous value is within and is returned. If the previous value is out of , then the pointer is not moved and is returned. The previous value is obtained by calling on the returned by the property.
If you set to , then is used to get the previous value. is subtracted from when is called. If is set to a negative value, then calling has the effect of increasing .

To change the range of values accepted by the control, create a new object with the desired values and assign it to the control using the property, as shown in the following example.
myNumericPointerControl.Range = new NationalInstruments.UI.Range(0, 100);

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.NumericPointer.EditRangeNumericFormatMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode used to format the value that is displayed when you click on an editable minimum or maximum value label on the scale.
member.value: A that is used to format the value that is displayed when you click on an editable minimum or maximum value label on the scale. The default value is a that formats the value as a double.

remarks.para: You can set this property to any instance of , including the format modes that the static methods return and any custom class that implements the base class.
The following format modes are available through the class:

item.description: Displays the value in a simple double format with a specified precision. Use the method to create an instance of a simple double format mode.

Displays the value using using standard numeric format strings. Refer to Standard Numeric Format Strings in the .NET Framework Developer's Guide for more information. Use the method to create an instance of a generic format mode.
Displays the value using format strings. Use the method to create an instance of an engineering format mode.
Displays the value in hexadecimal format. Use the method to create an instance of a hexadecimal format mode.
Displays the value in binary format. Use the method to create an instance of a binary format mode.
Displays the value using scientific notation format. Use the method to create an instance of a scientific format mode.

remarks.para: For more information, refer to the class.
For formatting modes such as generic and engineering, the value displayed for editing differs from the formatted value, so the user does not see the formatted value until the control loses focus.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.NumericPointer.EditRangeElapsedTimeFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format string that is used to format the value displayed when you click an editable minimum or maximum value label on a scale.
member.value: A representing standard or custom elapsed time format that is used to format the value to display when you click an editable minimum or maximum value label on a scale. The default value is a format mode created with "G".
member.exception: The string is not a valid standard or custom elapsed time format.

remarks.para:
You can set this property to a standard elapsed time format, such as 'c', 'g', or 'G', or a custom elapsed time format string. Refer to Using Elapsed Time Formats with Measurement Studio Windows Forms Controls or Using Elapsed Time Formats with Measurement Studio Web Forms Controls for information about valid standard and custom elapsed time formats.
When you use to update the minimum and maximum label values, you must input the value in the following format: [ws][-]{ d | d.hh:mm[:ss[.ff]]}[ws].

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.NumericPointer.EditRangeDateTimeFormatMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode used to format the value displayed when you click on an editable minimum or maximum value label on the scale.
member.value: A used to format the value displayed when you click on an editable minimum or maximum value label on the scale. The default value is a date time mode created by using .

remarks.para: You set this property to any instance of , including the format modes that the static methods return and any custom class that implements the base class.
The following format modes are available through the class:

item.description: Displays a combination of the short date and short time patterns, separated by a space. It uses the standard DateTime format specifier g. Refer to Standard DateTime Format Strings in the .NET Framework Developer's Guide for more information.

Displays a combination of the short date and long time patterns, separated by a space. It uses the standard DateTime format specifier G. Refer to Standard DateTime Format Strings in the .NET Framework Developer's Guide for more information.

remarks.para: For more information, refer to the class.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.RadialNumericPointer.HitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a that specifies where on the control the specified point is located.
member.param: The horizontal location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
The vertical location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
member.returns: A that specifies where on the control the and coordinate is located.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates using the method to determine where a user clicked on a object.
Public Sub RadialNumericPointer_MouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim hitTestRegion As RadialNumericPointerHitTestInfo Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))
hitTestRegion = radialNumeric.HitTest(e.X, e.Y) Select Case hitTestRegion Case RadialNumericPointerHitTestInfo.Dial radialNumeric.DialColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("The dial was clicked") Exit Select Case RadialNumericPointerHitTestInfo.OuterScaleArea Debug.WriteLine("The outer scale area was clicked") Exit Select Case RadialNumericPointerHitTestInfo.Pointer radialNumeric.PointerColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("The pointer was clicked") Exit Select Case RadialNumericPointerHitTestInfo.ScaleArea radialNumeric.ScaleBaseLineColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("The scale was clicked") Exit Select Case RadialNumericPointerHitTestInfo.None Debug.WriteLine("Unknown area was clicked") Exit Select End Select End Sub

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.RadialNumericPointer.InteractionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the user interactions that are supported by the control.
member.value: A that indicates which user interactions are supported by the control. The default value is .

remarks.para: Set to to enable interaction. If is , the has no effect regardless of its value.
The is changed according to the specified . Changing the interactively raises the and events.

The control supports interaction via the mouse and the keyboard. Click the left mouse button and drag the mouse to change the interactively. The mouse wheel can also be used to change the . To enable interaction using the mouse wheel, must be set to a value that includes . Scroll the mouse wheel up to move the pointer to the next value and down to move the pointer to the previous value. If the value is changed by clicking and dragging the mouse or using the mouse wheel, the and events are raised with the set to .

To enable interaction using the keyboard, must be set to a value that includes . To change the value using the keyboard, use the up or right arrow key to move the pointer to the next value and the down or left arrow key to move the pointer to the previous value. Changing the value using the keyboard raises the
and events with the set to . If is set to , the is used to determine the next and previous values.

If you set to allow keyboard or mouse interactions and is a negative value, then pressing the down or left arrow key or moving the scroll wheel down increases . Pressing the up or right arrow key or moving the scroll wheel up decreases .
Set to to wrap the pointer from the minimum of the to the maximum of the and vice versa. You cannot use when you change the pointer with the keyboard or mouse wheel.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Control Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.IntensityGraph
member.summary: Represents the class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms graphs that plot three-dimensional data on a two-dimensional plot with color representing the third dimension.

remarks.para: You can use the collection to include multiple instances on a single graph. With multiple plots, you can plot multiple sets of data in the same plot area.
Use to plot a two-dimensional rectangular array of values. Use or to append data to already plotted data.

collection allow multiple instance to coexist on a single graph. You can use multiple colorscales to plot multiple sets of data representing different colors. The event occurs when the collection is modified through an add, remove, insert, or clear operation. The is raised when the on an , contained in its collection, changes.

and collections allow multiple and instances to coexist on a single graph. You can use multiple axes to plot multiple sets of data that are scaled differently from each other. The event occurs when the collection is modified through an add, remove, insert, or clear operation. The event occurs when the collection is similarly modified.
raises when the on an , contained in its collection, changes. Similarly, occurs when the on a , contained in its collection, changes.

Custom drawn plots are supported through the and events. occurs before the plot is drawn. occurs after the plot is drawn. Use these events to participate in the drawing of a plot that is contained in the plot collection. occurs when a new set of data is plotted.

Plot area cursors are supported. You can use cursors to annotate plots and the plot area. accepts multiple cursors through the collection. The event occurs when the collection is modified through an add, remove, insert or clear operation. raises before an is moved and after the has completed moving.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Intensity Graph .NET Control Features
