member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.IntensityGraph.DrawOriginLines(NationalInstruments.UI.ComponentDrawArgs)
member.summary: Draws the origin lines in the plot area of the graph.
member.param: A that contains the drawing data.
member.remarks: provides an easy way to draw the origin lines while custom drawing the plot area. To custom draw the plot area, attach an event handler to or .
member.example:
The following example demonstrates drawing the origin lines of an object to a .png image file in response to the event.
Public Sub IntensityGraph_AfterDrawPlotArea(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As AfterDrawEventArgs) Dim imageFileName As String = "IntensityGraphOriginLinesImage.png" Using bmp As New Bitmap(intensityGraph.PlotAreaBounds.Width, intensityGraph.PlotAreaBounds.Height) Dim g As Graphics = Graphics.FromImage(bmp) Dim args As New ComponentDrawArgs(g, New Rectangle(0, 0, bmp.Width, bmp.Height))
intensityGraph.DrawOriginLines(args) bmp.Save(imageFileName, ImageFormat.Png) End Using Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("file {0} has been saved", imageFileName)) End Sub

The following example demonstrates appending a 2-D array of data to and existing IntensityGraph plot.
Dim zData As Double(,)

' ensure we can append the data in the horizontal direction If intensityGraph.Plots(0).HistoryCountY <> zData.GetLength(0) Then intensityGraph.ClearData() End If
' Append data horizontally, but do not transpose the data intensityGraph.PlotXAppend(zData, False)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.IntensityGraph.ZoomAroundPoint(System.Single,NationalInstruments.UI.IntensityPlot,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Zooms around the specified data point with the specified zoom factor and reference plot.
member.param: The percentage to zoom by.
An to use as the context for and .
The x data value to zoom around.
The y data value to zoom around.
member.remarks:
A value less than 1.0 indicates a zoom out, and a value greater than 1.0 indicates a zoom in. For example, a value of 0.8 zooms out by 80% and a value of 1.5 zooms in by 150%. If is set to 1.0, the plot area is not zoomed because a value of 1.0 zooms by 100% of the view.
The and values are mapped to client coordinates using the and properties, respectively, of . and act as the scale for mapping. The client coordinates are mapped to virtual coordinates using . The virtual coordinates are used to call .
member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming around a point on an obtained from handling the event.
Public Sub IntensityGraph_PlotAreaMouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim virtualPoint As PointF Dim xPos As Double, yPos As Double Dim rangeMin As Double, rangeMax As Double Dim zoomFactor As Single = 1.25F
' Only zoom in when the left mouse button is clicked. If e.Button = MouseButtons.Left Then ' Get the virtual position of the mouse click so that we can ' map to data coordinates on the graph. virtualPoint = intensityGraph.PointToVirtual(e.Location)
rangeMin = intensityGraph.XAxes(0).Range.Minimum rangeMax = intensityGraph.XAxes(0).Range.Maximum xPos = (rangeMax - rangeMin) * virtualPoint.X + rangeMin
rangeMin = intensityGraph.YAxes(0).Range.Minimum rangeMax = intensityGraph.YAxes(0).Range.Maximum yPos = (rangeMax - rangeMin) * virtualPoint.Y + rangeMin
intensityGraph.ZoomAroundPoint(zoomFactor, intensityGraph.Plots(0), xPos, yPos) End If End Sub

exception.para: The is less than or equal to 0.0.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.IntensityGraph.ZoomXY(NationalInstruments.UI.IntensityPlot,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Zooms to the region of the plot area specified by the x location, y location, region width, region height, and reference plot.
member.param: An to use as the context for , , and .

The y data value of the corner of the plot area region to zoom.
The width, in data units, of the plot area region to zoom.
The height, in data units, of the plot area region to zoom.

remarks.para: The is the left edge of the selection if the x-axis associated with is not inverted; otherwise, is the right edge of the selection. Similarly, is the bottom edge of the selection if the y-axis associated with is not inverted; otherwise, is the top edge of the selection.

The and values are mapped to client coordinates using the and properties, respectively, of . and act as the scale for mapping. The client coordinates are mapped to virtual coordinates using . The virtual coordinates are used to call .

member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming to a region defined by a rectangle.
Dim leftXPoint As Double = 10.0 Dim bottomYPoint As Double = 20.0 Dim height As Double = 15.0 Dim width As Double = 25.0
intensityGraph.ZoomXY(intensityGraph.Plots(0), leftXPoint, bottomYPoint, width, height)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.IntensityGraph.HitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a that specifies where on the control the specified point is located.
member.param: The horizontal location of the point to hit test, in client coordinates.
The vertical location of the point to hit test, in client coordinates.
member.returns: An that specifies where on the control the and coordinate is located.
member.remarks:
When hit testing a coordinate inside the plot area of the graph, respects the z-order of objects within the plot area. If two plots overlap at a particular coordinate, tests for the upper plot, and then tests for the lower plot.
If indicates an object exists, you can use , , , and to obtain a reference to the object.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates using the method to determine where a user clicked on a object.
Public Sub IntensityGraph_MouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim hitTestRegion As IntensityGraphHitTestInfo Dim plot As IntensityPlot Dim scale As ColorScale Dim index As Integer Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))
hitTestRegion = intensityGraph.HitTest(e.X, e.Y) Select Case hitTestRegion Case IntensityGraphHitTestInfo.ColorScale index = 0 scale = intensityGraph.GetColorScaleAt(e.X, e.Y) scale.CaptionBackColor = randomColor For Each entry As ColorMapEntry In scale.ColorMap Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Color map entry {0} has value {1} and color {2}", index, entry.Value, entry.Color.Name)) index = index + 1 Next Exit Select Case IntensityGraphHitTestInfo.Plot plot = intensityGraph.GetPlotAt(e.X, e.Y) Debug.WriteLine(string.Format("tooltips enabled: {0}", plot.ToolTipsEnabled)) Debug.WriteLine(string.Format("interpolation enabled: {0}", plot.PixelInterpolation)) Debug.WriteLine(string.Format("{0} x values", plot.HistoryCountX)) Debug.WriteLine(string.Format("{0} y values", plot.HistoryCountY)) Exit Select Case IntensityGraphHitTestInfo.PlotArea Debug.WriteLine("Plot area was clicked") Exit Select Case IntensityGraphHitTestInfo.XAxis Dim xAxis As IntensityXAxis = intensityGraph.GetXAxisAt(e.X, e.Y) xAxis.CaptionBackColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("X-Axis was clicked") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("X-Axis range minimum: {0}, X-Axis range maximum: {1}", xAxis.Range.Minimum, xAxis.Range.Maximum)) Exit Select Case IntensityGraphHitTestInfo.YAxis Dim yAxis As IntensityYAxis = intensityGraph.GetYAxisAt(e.X, e.Y) yAxis.CaptionBackColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Y-Axis was clicked") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Y-Axis range minimum: {0}, Y-Axis range maximum: {1}", yAxis.Range.Minimum, yAxis.Range.Maximum)) Exit Select Case IntensityGraphHitTestInfo.None Debug.WriteLine("Unknown graph area was clicked") Exit Select End Select End Sub

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Led.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new object that is a copy of this instance.
member.returns: A new object that is a copy of this instance.
member.remarks:
creates a new object that is a deep copy of .
A shallow copy creates a new instance of the same type as the original object, and then copies the nonstatic fields of the original object. If the field is a value type, a bit-by-bit copy of the field is performed. If the field is a reference type, the reference is copied but the referred object is not; therefore, the reference in the original object and the reference in the clone point to the same object. In contrast, a deep copy of an object duplicates everything directly or indirectly referenced by the fields in the object.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Legend
member.summary: Represents a Measurement Studio Windows Forms legend control to display symbols and descriptions of another object, such as the plots or cursors of a graph.

remarks.para: A legend control displays symbols and descriptions for a specific set of elements of another object, such as the plots or cursors of a graph. The size of each symbol in the legend control is determined by . contains a collection of objects that are displayed in the legend.

Custom-drawn legend items are supported through the and events. occurs before the legend item is drawn. occurs after the legend item is drawn. Use these events to participate in the drawing of a legend item that is contained in the collection.
remarks.note: For more information about the legend control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Legend .NET Control or Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Legend .NET Control Features.

member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Legend .NET Control
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Legend .NET Control Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Legend.HitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a that specifies where on the control the specified point is located.
member.param: The horizontal location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
The vertical location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
member.returns: A that specifies where on the control the and coordinate is located.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates using the method to determine where a user clicked on a object.
Public Sub Legend_MouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim hitTestRegion As LegendHitTestInfo Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))
hitTestRegion = legend.HitTest(e.X, e.Y) Select Case hitTestRegion Case LegendHitTestInfo.HorizontalScrollBar Debug.WriteLine("horizontal scrollbar selected") Exit Select Case LegendHitTestInfo.Item Dim item As LegendItem = legend.GetItemAt(e.X, e.Y) If TypeOf item.Source Is Plot Then Dim plot As Plot = DirectCast(item.Source, Plot) plot.LineColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Item selected was a Plot") ElseIf TypeOf item.Source Is DigitalPlot Then Dim plot As DigitalPlot = DirectCast(item.Source, DigitalPlot) plot.LineColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Item selected was a Digital Plot") End If Exit Select Case LegendHitTestInfo.Text Debug.WriteLine("Text area of legend selected") Exit Select Case LegendHitTestInfo.VerticalScrollBar Debug.WriteLine("vertical scrollbar selected") Exit Select Case LegendHitTestInfo.None Debug.WriteLine("Unknown legend area selected") Exit Select End Select End Sub

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.LinearNumericPointer
member.summary: Provides an base class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms numeric controls that display a numeric value in a linear scale.
member.remarks:
is the base class for numeric pointer controls that display a numeric value in a linear scale.
The supports interaction. Use to configure the suite of interactions provided by the control. Use to allow the pointer to be dragged. Use to snap the property to the mouse cursor. You can also change interactively using the up, down, left, and right arrow keys on the keyboard and by scrolling the mouse wheel.
You can use , , and to change the appearance of the fill and the fill area. Use to customize the direction of the fill, and use to set the value at which the fill begins. Use to invert the scale, and use to specify the horizontal or vertical orientation of the control.
determines the portion of the linear numeric pointer at a specified x and y location.
member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Control Features

Public Sub LinearNumericPointer_MouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim hitTestRegion As LinearNumericPointerHitTestInfo Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))
hitTestRegion = linearNumeric.HitTest(e.X, e.Y)
Select Case hitTestRegion Case LinearNumericPointerHitTestInfo.Fill linearNumeric.FillColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Filled area clicked") Exit Select Case LinearNumericPointerHitTestInfo.FillBackground linearNumeric.FillBackColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Fill background area clicked") Exit Select Case LinearNumericPointerHitTestInfo.Pointer linearNumeric.PointerColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Pointer clicked") Exit Select Case LinearNumericPointerHitTestInfo.ScaleArea linearNumeric.ScaleBaseLineColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("The scale area was clicked") Exit Select Case LinearNumericPointerHitTestInfo.None Debug.WriteLine("Unknown area clicked") Exit Select End Select End Sub

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.LinearNumericPointer.InteractionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the user interactions that are supported by the control.
member.value: A that indicates which user interactions are supported by the control. The default value is .

remarks.para: Set to to enable interaction. If is , the has no effect regardless of its value.
The is changed according to the specified . Changing the interactively raises the and events.

The control supports interaction via the mouse and the keyboard. Click the left mouse button and drag the mouse to change the interactively. The mouse wheel can also be used to change the . To enable interaction using the mouse wheel, must be set to a value that includes . Scroll the mouse wheel up to move the pointer to the next value and down to move the pointer to the previous value. If the value is changed by clicking and dragging the mouse or using the mouse wheel, the and events are raised with the set to .

To enable interaction using the keyboard, must be set to a value that includes . To change the value using the keyboard, use the up or right arrow key to move the pointer to the next value and the down or left arrow key to move the pointer to the previous value. Changing the value using the keyboard raises the
and events with the set to . If is set to , the is used to determine the next and previous values.

If you set to allow keyboard or mouse interactions and is a negative value, then pressing the down or left arrow key or moving the scroll wheel down increases . Pressing the up or right arrow key or moving the scroll wheel up decreases .

member.value: A that represents the position of the scale. The default value is .
member.exception: The value is not a value.
member.remarks: determines the orientation of the linear control. Setting to , , or draws the linear control with a vertical orientation. Setting to , , or draws the linear control with a horizontal orientation.

member.remarks:
Typically, you use as an indicator. You can use , , and to change the appearance of the .
The default values of and have been changed to give the control a more meter-like appearance. The default value of is an arc with a start angle of 150.0 and a sweep angle of -120.0. The default value of is .
For more information about the meter control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Controls.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.NumericEdit
member.summary: Represents a Measurement Studio Windows Forms numeric edit control to display and edit numeric values.

remarks.para: A numeric edit control stores and displays a double value. You can change the of the control using increment and decrement buttons, a text box, a mouse wheel, or up and down arrow keys.

Use the property to change how the user interacts with the control. Set to to disable user interaction. Set to a value that includes , , or to allow user interaction through text entry, the increment and decrement buttons, or the up and down arrow keys, respectively. If is set to a value that includes , the increment and decrement buttons are visible and you can use the mouse wheel to increment and decrement the value of the control. If is set to a value that does not include , the increment and decrement buttons are not visible and the mouse wheel does not affect the value of the control.

determines the format of the displayed value when viewing and editing the value of the control. provides a number of static methods that you can use to choose a common formatting mode. You can also create custom format modes for the numeric edit control by inheriting . For more information on creating a custom format mode, refer to Creating a Custom Format Mode for the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Edit .NET Control.
defines the range of valid values for the control. You can set the property to allow either continuous or discrete values.

The numeric edit control raises the event before the property changes and raises the event after the property changes. You can cancel the event to prevent the property from changing. The property of the event argument is set based on how the change was affected.

You can connect a numeric edit control to a knob, gauge, meter, slide, tank, or thermometer control such that changing the value of one control changes the value of the other control. To connect a numeric edit control to another control, set the property on to an implementation of the interface, such as a .
For more information about the numeric edit control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Edit .NET Control or Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Edit .NET Control Features.

member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Edit .NET Control
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Edit .NET Control Features
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Pointer .NET Control Features

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.NumericEdit.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new object that is a copy of this instance.
member.returns: A new object that is a copy of this instance.
member.remarks:
creates a new object that is a deep copy of .
A shallow copy creates a new instance of the same type as the original object, and then copies the nonstatic fields of the original object. If the field is a value type, a bit-by-bit copy of the field is performed. If the field is a reference type, the reference is copied but the referred object is not; therefore, the reference in the original object and the reference in the clone point to the same object. In contrast, a deep copy of an object duplicates everything directly or indirectly referenced by the fields in the object.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.NumericEdit.FormatMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode used to format the value of the control.
member.value: A that is used to format the value of the control. The default value is a that formats the value as a double.

remarks.para: You can set this property to any instance of , including the format modes that the static methods return and any custom class that implements the base class.
The following format modes are available through the class:

item.description: Displays the value in a simple double format with a specified precision. Use the method to create an instance of a simple double format mode.

Displays the value using standard numeric format strings. Refer to Standard Numeric Format Strings in the .NET Framework Developer's Guide for more information. Use the method to create an instance of a generic format mode.
Displays the value using format strings. Use the method to create an instance of an engineering format mode.
Displays the value in hexadecimal format. Use the method to create an instance of a hexadecimal format mode.
Displays the value in binary format. Use the method to create an instance of a binary format mode.
Displays the value using scientific notation format. Use the method to create an instance of a scientific format mode.

remarks.para: For more information, refer to the class.

The numeric edit control does not apply the formatting specified by until the control loses focus. For formatting modes such as generic and engineering, the value displayed for editing differs from the formatted value, so the user does not see the formatted value until the control loses focus.

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Edit .NET Control Features

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.NumericEdit.InteractionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the user interactions that are supported by the control.
member.value: A that indicates which interaction modes are supported by the control. The default value is a bitwise combination of , , and .

remarks.para: Set to to enable interaction. If is , the property has no effect regardless of its value.
The property changes according to the specified . Changing the interactively raises the and events.
The control supports interaction using the mouse and the keyboard. If is set to a value that includes , the up and down buttons are visible on the control.

Click the up or down buttons on the control to change the property interactively. You can also use the mouse wheel to change the property. To enable interaction using the mouse wheel, you must set to a value that includes . Scroll the mouse wheel up to increment the value of the control and down to decrement the value of the control. If you change the value by clicking the mouse or using the mouse wheel, the and events are raised with the property set to .

To change the value of the control by entering a new value with the keyboard, set
to a value that includes . To change the value using the up or down arrow keys, you must set
to a value that includes . Use the up arrow key to increment the value of the control and the down arrow key to decrement the value of the control. Changing the value using the keyboard raises the
and events with the property set to . If is set to , the property is used to determine the next and previous values when incrementing or decrementing.

If you set to allow keyboard or mouse interactions and is a negative value, then pressing the down or left arrow key, moving the scroll wheel down, or clicking the lower button on the control increases . Pressing the up or right arrow key, moving the scroll wheel up, or clicking the upper button on the control decreases .

member.seealso: Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Numeric Edit .NET Control Features

member.exception: The assigned value is not one of the values.
member.remarks: Use this property to change the side of the control on which the buttons are drawn.

member.value: A Windows Forms control that implements . The default value is .

remarks.para: When you set to a valid control, the , , , and properties of the have no effect and the properties of the source control are used instead.
When you set to , the is not connected to another control.
If the value of the numeric edit control changes as a result of setting , the and events are raised. However, the event is not raised because the value change event cannot be cancelled.

member.summary: Gets or sets the interval used for coercing the value.
member.value: The interval used for incrementing, decrementing, and coercing the value of the control. The default value is 1.
member.remarks:
When you increment or decrement the value of the control using the up and down buttons or the and methods, determines the magnitude of the change.
Use when is set to . specifies the base value and specifies the distance to the next discrete value from the .
Set the property to and set the and properties to coerce the value of the control to discrete values. For example, set to 0 and set to 2 to coerce the value to even values.
When you set to a valid control, the property has no effect and the interval of the source control is used instead.
is subtracted from when is called. is added to when is called. If is set to a negative value, then calling has the effect of increasing and calling has the effect of decreasing . Also, if you set to allow keyboard or mouse interactions, then pressing the down or left arrow key, moving the scroll wheel down, or clicking the lower button on the control increases . Pressing the up or right arrow key, moving the scroll wheel up, or clicking the upper button on the control decreases .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.PropertyEditor
member.summary: Represents the class for a Measurement Studio .NET Windows Forms control that edits property values at run time.
member.remarks:
Use the control to edit property values at run time using their associated editors. The editor displayed by the control is the same editor that is displayed when you edit the property at design time.
represents the property to edit. To edit a property of an object, you must set the source property with an object reference and property name on that object. Use to specify the value of the property being edited. Call to launch the associated editor programmatically. If the cannot be converted to a valid string representation, the event is raised. Use the event to set the to a valid value.
Calling on a Windows Form containing a control which points to a Measurement Studio graph, such as a or , from a non-UI thread, results in an InvalidCastException at the statement. This exception occurs because the non-UI thread is making underlying calls to COM objects. Therefore, the non-UI thread needs to be set to run in a single-threaded apartment. To set the of the thread created, call on the non-UI thread and set the state to ApartmentState.STA. Call the method before starting the thread.
You must call on the after you have finished using it to reclaim memory and perform cleanup.
The control relies on designer services that may not always be available at run time. This may cause the editor to behave differently compared to the behavior exhibited in the designer. For example, you cannot cancel changes made in the collection editor for properties whose type is a collection.
member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Property Editor .NET Control

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ScatterGraph
member.summary: Represents the class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms graphs that accept both x and y data values.
member.remarks:
The ability to specify x and y data values allows you to plot non-monotonically increasing data.
You can use the collection to include multiple instances on a single graph. With multiple plots, you can plot multiple sets of data in the same plot area. You can determine whether plot colors are assigned by a color generator with the property, and you can change the plot color assignment with the property.
Use to plot a single y value against a single x value or an array of y values against an array of x values. plots y values against x values by appending the x and y values to the existing data.
You can plot multiple sets of y data values against a single set of x data values with a single method invocation. Use to plot a 2D array of y values against an array of x values. behaves in much the same way, except that it appends the data to the existing data for plotting. plots a 2D array of x values against an array of y values. behaves similarly but appends the data to the existing data.
For more information about the scatter graph control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls or Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Scatter and Waveform Graph .NET Control Features.
member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Scatter and Waveform Graph .NET Control Features

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.XYGraph
member.summary: Provides an base class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms graphs that plot data on a set of x and y axes.

remarks.para: accepts data as a .

and collections allow multiple x and y axes to coexist on a single graph. You can use multiple axes to plot multiple sets of data that are scaled differently from each other. The event occurs when the collection is modified through an add, remove, insert, or clear operation. The event occurs when the collection is similarly modified.

raises when the on an , contained in its collection, changes. Similarly, occurs when the
on a , contained in its collection, changes.

Custom drawn plots are supported through the and events. occurs before the plot is drawn. occurs after the plot is drawn. Use these events to participate in the drawing of a plot that is contained in the plot collection. occurs when a new set of data is plotted.

Plot area cursors are supported. You can use cursors to annotate plots and the plot area. accepts multiple cursors through the collection. The event occurs when the collection is modified through an add, remove, insert, or clear operation. raises before an is moved and after the cursor has completed moving.

returns the plot at the specified location in client coordinates along with the data value and the index to the data value. To provide additional functionality when the end user performs interactive actions on the plot using the mouse in the plot area of the graph, use in conjunction with the plot area mouse events such as and .
remarks.note: For more information about the XY graph control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls.

member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.XYGraph.ZoomAroundPoint(System.Single,NationalInstruments.UI.XYPlot,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Zooms around the specified data point with the specified zoom factor and reference plot.
member.param: The percentage to zoom by.
An to use as the context for and .
The x data value to zoom around.
The y data value to zoom around.

exception.para: The is less than or equal to 0.0.

member.remarks:
A value less than 1.0 indicates a zoom out, and a value greater than 1.0 indicates a zoom in. For example, a value of 0.8 zooms out by 80%, and a value of 1.5 zooms in by 150%. If is set to 1.0, the plot area is not zoomed because a value of 1.0 zooms by 100% of the view.
The and values are mapped to client coordinates using the and properties, respectively, of . and act as the scale for mapping. The client coordinates are mapped to virtual coordinates using . The virtual coordinates are used to call .
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about zooming interactively.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming in by 125% around a point on an object. The point to zoom around is determined by handling the event.
Public Sub XYGraph_PlotAreaMouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim virtualPoint As PointF Dim xPos As Double, yPos As Double Dim rangeMin As Double, rangeMax As Double Dim zoomFactor As Single = 1.25F
' only zoom in when the left mouse button is clicked If e.Button = MouseButtons.Left Then ' get the virtual position of the mouse click so that we can ' map to data coordinates on the graph. virtualPoint = xyGraph.PointToVirtual(e.Location)
rangeMin = xyGraph.XAxes(0).Range.Minimum rangeMax = xyGraph.XAxes(0).Range.Maximum xPos = (rangeMax - rangeMin) * virtualPoint.X + rangeMin
rangeMin = xyGraph.YAxes(0).Range.Minimum rangeMax = xyGraph.YAxes(0).Range.Maximum yPos = (rangeMax - rangeMin) * virtualPoint.Y + rangeMin
xyGraph.ZoomAroundPoint(zoomFactor, xyPlot, xPos, yPos) End If End Sub
member.seealso: Converting Data Types Using Measurement Studio DataConverter

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.XYGraph.ZoomXY(NationalInstruments.UI.XYPlot,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Zooms to the region of the plot area specified by the x location, y location, region width, region height, and reference plot.
member.param: An to use as the context for , , , and .
The x data value of the corner of the plot area region to zoom.
The y data value of the corner of the plot area region to zoom.
The width in data units of the plot area region to zoom.
The height in data units of the plot area region to zoom.

remarks.para: The is the left edge of the selection if the x-axis associated with is not inverted. Otherwise, is the right edge of the selection. Similarly, is the bottom edge of the selection if the y-axis associated with is not inverted. Otherwise, is the top edge of the selection.

The and values are mapped to client coordinates using the and properties, respectively, of . and act as the scale for mapping. The client coordinates are mapped to virtual coordinates using . Use the virtual coordinates to call .
determines if an animated visual cue is drawn based on the value of .
Calling raises the event with set to .
Refer to for information about zooming interactively.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates zooming to a specifically sized rectangle on an plot.
Dim leftXPoint As Double = 2.0 Dim bottomYPoint As Double = 3.0 Dim height As Double = 2.0 Dim width As Double = 3.0
xyGraph.ZoomXY(xyPlot, leftXPoint, bottomYPoint, width, height)
member.seealso: Converting Data Types Using Measurement Studio DataConverter

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.XYGraph.HitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a that specifies where on the control the specified point is located.
member.param: The horizontal location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
The vertical location of the point to be hit-tested, in client coordinates.
member.returns: A that specifies where on the control the and coordinate is located.
member.remarks:
When hit-testing a coordinate inside the plot area of the graph, respects the z-order of objects within the plot area. If a cursor, plot, and annotation overlap at a particular coordinate, will test for cursor, plot, and annotation in that order.
If indicates an object exists, you can use , , , , and to obtain a reference to the object.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates using the method to determine where a user clicked on an object.
Public Sub XYGraph_MouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As MouseEventArgs) Dim hitTestRegion As XYGraphHitTestInfo Dim plot As XYPlot Dim index As Integer Dim randomColor As Color = Color.FromArgb(RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255), RandNumberGenerator.[Next](255))
hitTestRegion = xyGraph.HitTest(e.X, e.Y) Select Case hitTestRegion Case XYGraphHitTestInfo.Annotation Dim annot As XYPointAnnotation = TryCast(xyGraph.GetAnnotationAt(e.X, e.Y), XYPointAnnotation) annot.ShapeFillColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Annotation selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Annotation X position: {0}, Annotation Y position {1}", annot.XPosition.ToString(), annot.YPosition.ToString())) Exit Select Case XYGraphHitTestInfo.Cursor Dim cursor As XYCursor = xyGraph.GetCursorAt(e.X, e.Y) cursor.Color = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Cursor selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Cursor X position: {0}, Cursor Y position: {1}", cursor.XPosition.ToString(), cursor.YPosition.ToString())) Exit Select Case XYGraphHitTestInfo.ErrorBand Dim xVal As Double, yVal As Double, xErrData As Double, yErrData As Double Dim xErrString As String, yErrString As String
plot = xyGraph.GetErrorBandAt(e.X, e.Y, xErrData, yErrData, index) plot.LineColor = randomColor xVal = CDbl(plot.GetXData().GetValue(index)) yVal = CDbl(plot.GetYData().GetValue(index))
If xErrData > xVal Then xErrString = "upper bound is " & xErrData.ToString(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture) ElseIf xErrData < xVal Then xErrString = "lower bound is " & xErrData.ToString(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture) Else xErrString = "is not set" End If
If yErrData > yVal Then yErrString = "upper bound is " & yErrData.ToString(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture) ElseIf yErrData < yVal Then yErrString = "lower bound is " & yErrData.ToString(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture) Else yErrString = "is not set" End If
Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("The x error data {0}{1}The y error data {2}", xErrString, Environment.NewLine, yErrString)) Exit Select Case XYGraphHitTestInfo.Plot Dim xData As Double, yData As Double
plot = xyGraph.GetPlotAt(e.X, e.Y, xData, yData, index) plot.LineColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Data point {0} is located at ({1}, {2})", index, xData, yData)) Exit Select Case XYGraphHitTestInfo.PlotArea Debug.WriteLine("Plot area was clicked") Exit Select Case XYGraphHitTestInfo.XAxis Dim xAxis As XAxis = xyGraph.GetXAxisAt(e.X, e.Y) xAxis.CaptionBackColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("XAxis Selected") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("X-Axis range minimum: {0}, X-Axis range maximum: {1}", xAxis.Range.Minimum, xAxis.Range.Maximum)) Exit Select Case XYGraphHitTestInfo.YAxis Dim yAxis As YAxis = xyGraph.GetYAxisAt(e.X, e.Y) yAxis.CaptionBackColor = randomColor Debug.WriteLine("Y-Axis was clicked") Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("Y-Axis range minimum: {0}, Y-Axis range maximum: {1}", yAxis.Range.Minimum, yAxis.Range.Maximum)) Exit Select Case XYGraphHitTestInfo.None Debug.WriteLine("Unknown graph area was clicked") Exit Select End Select End Sub

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.XYGraph.DrawOriginLines(NationalInstruments.UI.ComponentDrawArgs)
member.summary: Draws the origin lines in the plot area of the graph.
member.param: A that contains the drawing data.
member.remarks: Use to draw the origin lines while custom drawing the plot area. To custom draw the plot area, attach an event handler to or .
member.example:
The following example demonstrates drawing the origin lines of an object to a .png image file in response to the event.
Public Sub XYGraph_AfterDrawPlotArea(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As AfterDrawEventArgs) Dim imageFileName As String = "XYGraphOriginLinesImage.png" Using bmp As New Bitmap(xyGraph.PlotAreaBounds.Width, xyGraph.PlotAreaBounds.Height) Dim g As Graphics = Graphics.FromImage(bmp) Dim args As New ComponentDrawArgs(g, New Rectangle(0, 0, bmp.Width, bmp.Height))
xyGraph.DrawOriginLines(args) bmp.Save(imageFileName, ImageFormat.Png) End Using Debug.WriteLine(String.Format("file {0} has been saved", imageFileName)) End Sub

You must provide all of the implementation for drawing the plot if is set to .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ScatterGraph.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by the and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: to release both managed and unmanaged resources; to release only unmanaged resources.
member.remarks:
This method is called by the public method and the finalizer. invokes the protected Dispose(Boolean) method with the parameter set to . The finalizer invokes with set to .
When the parameter is , this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this references. This method invokes the of each referenced object.
can be called multiple times by other objects. When overriding Dispose(Boolean), be careful not to reference objects that have been previously disposed of in an earlier call to .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ScatterGraph.PlotLineColorGenerator
member.summary: Gets or sets the that assigns different colors to plots.
member.value: The that assigns different colors to plots. The default value is .
member.remarks:
At design time, when you add, delete, or move a plot up and down, the colors are reassigned according to the order in which they are specified in the color set. At run time, the color of the plot depends on its index in the plot collection when you add the plot to the collection. If you delete a plot at run time, the color of the other plots does not change.
When this property changes, the event is raised, and colors are assigned to all plots if is .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.ScatterGraph.UseColorGenerator
member.summary: Gets or sets whether is enabled or disabled.
member.value: to enable ; otherwise, . The default value is .
member.remarks:
When this property is set to , plots are assigned different colors by the property; otherwise, the plots default to , unless you have explicitly set the colors. determines whether to draw the plot with auto-generated color or with a color you assign.
At design time, this property is set to by a custom control designer for ease of use.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.Switch.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new object that is a copy of this instance.
member.returns: A new object that is a copy of this instance.
member.remarks:
creates a new object that is a deep copy of .
A shallow copy creates a new instance of the same type as the original object, and then copies the nonstatic fields of the original object. If the field is a value type, a bit-by-bit copy of the field is performed. If the field is a reference type, the reference is copied but the referred object is not; therefore, the reference in the original object and the reference in the clone point to the same object. In contrast, a deep copy of an object duplicates everything directly or indirectly referenced by the fields in the object.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.WaveformGraph
member.summary: Represents the class for Measurement Studio Windows Forms graphs that accept data as a waveform.

remarks.para: A waveform is defined as a set of data against equally spaced increments.

You can use the collection to include multiple instances on a single graph. With multiple plots, you can plot multiple sets of data in the same plot area. You can determine whether plot colors are assigned by a color generator with the property, and you can change the plot color assignment with the property.

Use to plot a single x value or an array of x values against a starting y value.
uses the specified value to increment y values or a default value if one is not specified. plots x values by appending the values to the existing data.

You can plot multiple sets of x data values with a single method invocation. Use to plot a 2D array of x values against a starting y value. uses the specified value to increment y values or a default value if one is not specified. behaves in much the same way, except that it appends the data to the existing data for plotting.

Use to plot a single y value or an array of y values against a starting x value. uses the specified value to increment x values or a default value if one is not specified. plots y values by appending the values to the existing data.

You can plot multiple sets of y data values with a single method invocation. Use to plot a 2D array of y values against a starting x value. uses a specified value to increment x values or a default value if one is not specified. behaves in much the same way, except that it appends the data to the existing data for plotting.

para.filter: You can use to plot or data against the waveform sample units and to append the waveform to the existing data.
You can use to plot data against the waveform sample units and to append the waveform to the existing data.

Use to plot a 1D array of or data against the waveform sample units or use to append an array to the existing data. Similarly, you can use to plot a 2D array of or data against the waveform sample units and to append the waveforms against the existing data.

Use to plot a 1D array of data against the waveform sample units or use to append an array to the existing data. Similarly, you can use to plot a 2D array of data against the waveform sample units and to append the waveforms against the existing data.

remarks.para: You can use to plot data and to append the waveform to the existing data.
Use to plot a 1D array of data or use to append an array to the existing data. Similarly, you can use to plot a 2D array of data and to append the waveforms against the existing data.
can be used to bind the graph to a data source. The method to invoke when bound to a data source is specified by the value of .
remarks.note: For more information about the waveform graph control, refer to Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls or Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Scatter and Waveform Graph .NET Control Features.

member.seealso: Using the Measurement Studio Windows Forms Graph .NET Controls
Key Measurement Studio Windows Forms Scatter and Waveform Graph .NET Control Features

This method is called by the public method and the finalizer. invokes the protected Dispose(Boolean) method with the parameter set to . The finalizer invokes with set to .
When the parameter is , this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this references. This method invokes the of each referenced object.
can be called multiple times by other objects. When overriding Dispose(Boolean), be careful not to reference objects that have been previously disposed of in an earlier call to .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.WaveformGraph.PlotXAppendMultiple(System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: Plots a 2D array of x values with the default data orientation against a starting y value by appending the x and y values to the existing data.
member.param: The 2D array of x values to plot.

remarks.para: The orientation of data in is specified by .

This method calls on instances in using the index of rows or columns of based on the value of . The value of the plot is used as the starting y value if there is no existing data; otherwise, the starting y value is determined by adding the value of the plot to the last y value in the existing data. The value of the plot is used for incrementing y values.

If there are not enough plots available in , additional instances are created and added to the collection as required. The implicitly created instances are associated with the first and first in and , respectively. If or are empty, an additional or is created and added to the collection.

To prevent an exception from being thrown, call on the plot after calling , , , , , or , but before calling . Refer to on the plot to determine the category of the method that is currently being used to plot data.

To successfully change the increment from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to plot an array of x values that represents a 1D double array. You can use the code to plot a single data point across multiple plots. This example assumes that a called waveformGraph1 has been declared and initialized.
Dim xValues As Double() = {2, 4, 6, 8, 10} Dim xValuesMatrix As Double(,) = CType(NationalInstruments.DataConverter.Convert(xValues, GetType(Double(,))), Double(,)) waveformGraph1.DefaultDataOrientation = DataOrientation.DataInColumns waveformGraph1.PlotXAppendMultiple(xValuesMatrix)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.WaveformGraph.PlotXAppendMultiple(System.Double[0:,0:],NationalInstruments.UI.DataOrientation,System.Double)
member.summary: Plots a 2D array of x values with the specified orientation against a starting y value by appending the x and y values to the existing data using the specified value to increment y values.
member.param: The 2D array of x values to append.
A value that specifies the orientation of data in .
The value to use to increment y values.

remarks.para:
This method calls on instances in using the index of rows or columns of based on the value of . The value of the plot is used as the starting y value if there is no existing data; otherwise, the starting y value is determined by adding
to the last y value in the existing data.

If there are not enough plots available in , additional instances are created and added to the collection as required. The implicitly created instances are associated with the first and first in and , respectively. If or are empty, an additional or is created and added to the collection.

To prevent an exception from being thrown, call on the plot after calling , , , , , or , but before calling . Refer to on the plot to determine the category of the method that is currently being used to plot data.

To successfully change from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to plot an array of x values that represents a 1D double array. You can use the code to plot a single data point across multiple plots. This example assumes that a called waveformGraph1 has been declared and initialized.
Dim xValues As Double() = {2, 4, 6, 8, 10} Dim xValuesMatrix As Double(,) = CType(NationalInstruments.DataConverter.Convert(xValues, GetType(Double(,))), Double(,)) waveformGraph1.PlotXAppendMultiple(xValuesMatrix, DataOrientation.DataInColumns, 1)

The following example demonstrates appending multiple sets of data organized in rows at an increment of 1.5.
Dim xData As Double(,) = New Double(2, 49) {} Dim amp As Double
' Create random x data. For row As Integer = 0 To xData.GetLength(0) - 1 amp = RandNumberGenerator.NextDouble() * 10 For col As Integer = 0 To xData.GetLength(1) - 1 xData(row, col) = amp * Math.Sin(2 * col * Math.PI / xData.GetLength(1)) + amp Next Next
' Set the X-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.XAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString ' Set the Y-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.YAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString
If wvfmGraph.Plots(0).Mode < > WaveformPlotMode.PlotX Then wvfmGraph.ClearData() End If ' Plot all elements of the xData array, incrementing ' Y values 1.5 units per xData element. Because there are ' three rows of data, specify the DataOrientation to be in rows wvfmGraph.PlotXAppendMultiple(xData, DataOrientation.DataInRows, 1.5)

The following example demonstrates how to plot an array of x values that represents a 1D double array. You can use the code to plot a single data point across multiple plots. This example assumes that a called waveformGraph1 has been declared and initialized.

The following example demonstrates appending multiple sets of data organized in columns at an increment of 2.75 seconds.
Dim xData As Double(,) = New Double(49, 2) {} Dim amp As Double Dim increment As TimeSpan = TimeSpan.FromSeconds(2.75)

' Set the X-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.XAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString ' Set the Y-Axis to display time wvfmGraph.YAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = timeFormatString
If wvfmGraph.Plots(0).Mode <> WaveformPlotMode.PlotX Then wvfmGraph.ClearData() End If ' Plot all elements of the xData array, incrementing ' Y values by 2.75 seconds with each value. Because there are three ' columns of data, specify the DataOrientation to be in columns wvfmGraph.PlotXAppendMultiple(xData, DataOrientation.DataInColumns, increment)

member.summary: Plots an array of x values against a starting y value by appending the x and y values to the existing data using the specified value to increment y values.
member.param: The array of x values to append.
The value to use to increment y values.

remarks.para: This method calls on the first in . The value of the plot is used as the starting y value if there is no existing data; otherwise, the starting y value is determined by adding to the last y value in the existing data.

If there are not enough plots available in , additional instances are created and added to the collection as required. The implicitly created instances are associated with the first and first in and , respectively. If or are empty, an additional or is created and added to the collection.

To prevent an exception from being thrown, call on the plot after calling , , , , , or , but before calling . Refer to on the plot to determine the category of the method that is currently being used to plot data.

To successfully change from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.
To call on another plot in the collection, use the indexer provided by to obtain a reference to the plot, and then call on the plot reference.

member.param: The array of x values to append.
The index in at which the plot data begins.
The number of elements, beginning at in , to plot.
The value used to increment y values.

remarks.para: This method calls on the first in . The value of the plot is used as the starting y value if there is no existing data; otherwise, the starting y value is determined by adding to the last y value in the existing data.

If there are not enough plots available in , additional instances are created and added to the collection as required. The implicitly created instances are associated with the first and first in and , respectively. If or are empty, an additional or is created and added to the collection.

To prevent an exception from being thrown, call on the plot after calling , , , , , or , but before calling . Refer to on the plot to determine the category of the method that is currently being used to plot data.

To successfully change from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.
To call on another plot in the collection, use the indexer provided by to obtain a reference to the plot, and then call on the plot reference.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates appending a subset of x values with a y increment of 1.5.
' Create random x data.. Dim xData As Double() = New Double(49) {} Dim amp As Double = RandNumberGenerator.NextDouble() * 10
For i As Integer = 0 To xData.Length - 1 xData(i) = amp * Math.Sin(2 * i * Math.PI / xData.Length) + amp Next
' Set the X-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.XAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString ' Set the Y-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.YAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString
If wvfmGraph.Plots(0).Mode <> WaveformPlotMode.PlotX Then wvfmGraph.ClearData() End If ' Plot all elements of the xData array, incrementing ' Y values 1.5 units per xData element. wvfmGraph.PlotXAppend(xData, 0, xData.Length, 1.5)

The following example demonstrates appending a subset of an array of x values with a y increment of 1 second and a specified PlotDateTimePrecisionMode of Default.
' Create random x data. Dim xData As Double() = New Double(49) {} Dim amp As Double = RandNumberGenerator.NextDouble() * 10
For i As Integer = 0 To xData.Length - 1 xData(i) = amp * Math.Sin(2 * i * Math.PI / xData.Length) + amp Next
' Set the X-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.XAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString ' Set the Y-Axis to display time wvfmGraph.YAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = timeFormatString
If wvfmGraph.Plots(0).Mode <> WaveformPlotMode.PlotX Then wvfmGraph.ClearData() End If ' Plot 6 elements from the xData array beginning from the element at index 2. ' Increment Y values at 1 second per element, with default precision wvfmGraph.PlotXAppend(xData, 2, 6, TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1.0), PlotDateTimePrecisionMode.[Default])

The following example demonstrates plotting a subset of an array of x values against the starting y value of and the specified value.
' Create random x data. Dim xData As Double() = New Double(49) {} Dim amp As Double = RandNumberGenerator.NextDouble() * 10 Dim increment As TimeSpan = TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1.0) Dim stamp As DateTime = DateTime.Now
For i As Integer = 0 To xData.Length - 1 xData(i) = amp * Math.Sin(2 * i * Math.PI / xData.Length) + amp Next
' Set the x axis to display samples. wvfmGraph.XAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString ' Set the y axis to display time. wvfmGraph.YAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = timeFormatString
If wvfmGraph.Plots(0).Mode <> WaveformPlotMode.PlotX Then wvfmGraph.ClearData() End If ' Plot 6 elements from the xData array beginning from the element at index 2. ' Increment y values at 1 second per element, with default precision. wvfmGraph.PlotX(xData, 2, 6, stamp, increment, PlotDateTimePrecisionMode.[Default])

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.WaveformGraph.PlotYAppendMultiple(System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: Plots a 2D array of y values with the default data orientation against a starting x value by appending it to the existing data.
member.param: The 2D array of y values to plot.

remarks.para: The orientation of data in is specified by .

This method calls on instances in using the index of rows or columns of based on the value of . The value of the plot is used as the starting x value if there is no existing data; otherwise, the starting x value is determined by adding the value of the plot to the last x value in the existing data. The value of the plot is used for incrementing x values.

If there are not enough plots available in , additional instances are created and added to the collection as required. The implicitly created instances are associated with the first and first in and , respectively. If or are empty, an additional or is created and added to the collection.

To prevent an exception from being thrown, call on the plot after calling , , , , , or , but before calling . Refer to on the plot to determine the category of the method that is currently being used to plot data.

To successfully change the increment from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to plot an array of x values that represents a 1D double array. You can use the code to plot a single data point across multiple plots. This example assumes that a called waveformGraph1 has been declared and initialized.
Dim yValues As Double() = {2, 4, 6, 8, 10} Dim yValuesMatrix As Double(,) = CType(NationalInstruments.DataConverter.Convert(yValues, GetType(Double(,))), Double(,)) waveformGraph1.DefaultDataOrientation = DataOrientation.DataInColumns waveformGraph1.PlotYAppendMultiple(yValuesMatrix)

member.param: The 2D array of y values to append.

The value to use to increment x values.

remarks.para:
This method calls on instances in using the index of rows or columns of based on the value of . The value of the plot is used as the starting x value if there is no existing data; otherwise, the starting x value is determined by adding
to the last x value in the existing data.

If there are not enough plots available in , additional instances are created and added to the collection as required. The implicitly created instances are associated with the first and first in and , respectively. If or are empty, an additional or is created and added to the collection.

To successfully change from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to plot an array of x values that represents a 1D double array. You can use the code to plot a single data point across multiple plots. This example assumes that a called waveformGraph1 has been declared and initialized.
Dim yValues As Double() = {2, 4, 6, 8, 10} Dim yValuesMatrix As Double(,) = CType(NationalInstruments.DataConverter.Convert(yValues, GetType(Double(,))), Double(,)) waveformGraph1.PlotYAppendMultiple(yValuesMatrix, DataOrientation.DataInColumns, 1)

The following example demonstrates appending multiple y data sets orgainized in rows incrementing at an interval of 3.0.
Dim yData As Double(,) = New Double(2, 49) {} Dim amp As Double
' Create sinusoidal y data For row As Integer = 0 To yData.GetLength(0) - 1 amp = RandNumberGenerator.NextDouble() * 10 For col As Integer = 0 To yData.GetLength(1) - 1 yData(row, col) = amp * Math.Sin(2 * col * Math.PI / yData.GetLength(0)) + amp Next Next
' Set the X-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.XAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString ' Set the Y-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.YAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString
If wvfmGraph.Plots(0).Mode <> WaveformPlotMode.PlotY Then wvfmGraph.ClearData() End If ' Plot all elements of the yData array, incrementing ' X values by 3 with each value. Because there are three ' rows of data, specify the DataOrientation to be in rows wvfmGraph.PlotYAppendMultiple(yData, DataOrientation.DataInRows, 3.0)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.WaveformGraph.PlotYAppendMultiple(System.Double[0:,0:],NationalInstruments.UI.DataOrientation,System.TimeSpan,NationalInstruments.UI.PlotDateTimePrecisionMode)
member.summary: Plots a 2D array of y values with the specified orientation against a starting y value with the specified . appends the x and y values to the existing data using the specified to increment x values.
member.param: The 2D array of y values to append.
A value that specifies the orientation of data in .
A that represents the value to use to increment x values.
A that represents the precision mode to use when plotting the y values.

remarks.para:
This method calls on instances in using the index of rows or columns of based on the value of . The value of the plot is used as the starting x value if there is no existing data; otherwise, the starting x value is determined by adding
to the last x value in the existing data.

If there are not enough plots available in , additional instances are created and added to the collection as required. The implicitly created instances are associated with the first and first in and , respectively. If or are empty, an additional or is created and added to the collection.

To prevent an exception from being thrown, call on the plot after calling , , , , , or , but before calling . Refer to on the plot to determine the category of the method that is currently being used to plot data.

To successfully change from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates appending multiple y data sets orgainized in columns incrementing at an interval of 2.75 seconds.
Dim yData As Double(,) = New Double(49, 2) {} Dim amp As Double Dim increment As TimeSpan = TimeSpan.FromSeconds(2.75)
' Create sinusoidal y data For col As Integer = 0 To yData.GetLength(1) - 1 amp = RandNumberGenerator.NextDouble() * 10 For row As Integer = 0 To yData.GetLength(0) - 1 yData(row, col) = amp * Math.Sin(2 * row * Math.PI / yData.GetLength(0)) + amp Next Next
' Set the X-Axis to display time wvfmGraph.XAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = timeFormatString ' Set the Y-Axis to display samples wvfmGraph.YAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString
If wvfmGraph.Plots(0).Mode <> WaveformPlotMode.PlotY Then wvfmGraph.ClearData() End If ' Plot all elements of the yData array, incrementing ' X values by 2.75 seconds with each value. Because there are three ' columns of data, specify the DataOrientation to be in columns wvfmGraph.PlotYAppendMultiple(yData, DataOrientation.DataInColumns, increment, PlotDateTimePrecisionMode.[Default])

The following example demonstrates how to plot an array of x values that represents a 1D double array. You can use the code to plot a single data point across multiple plots. This example assumes that a called waveformGraph1 has been declared and initialized.
Dim yValues As Double() = {2, 4, 6, 8, 10} Dim yValuesMatrix As Double(,) = CType(NationalInstruments.DataConverter.Convert(yValues, GetType(Double(,))), Double(,)) waveformGraph1.PlotYAppendMultiple(yValuesMatrix, DataOrientation.DataInColumns, TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1), PlotDateTimePrecisionMode.Precise)

To successfully change the increment from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.

remarks.para: This method calls on the first in . The value of the plot is used as the starting x value if there is no existing data; otherwise, the starting x value is determined by adding to the last x value in the existing data.

If there are not enough plots available in , additional instances are created and added to the collection as required. The implicitly created instances are associated with the first and first in and , respectively. If or are empty, an additional or is created and added to the collection.

To prevent an exception from being thrown, call on the plot after calling , , , , , or , but before calling . Refer to on the plot to determine the category of the method that is currently being used to plot data.

To successfully change from a previously negative value to a positive value or from a previously positive value to a negative value, call on the plot before changing the value. Refer to of the plot to determine the polarity of the currently used increment.
To call on another plot in the collection, use the indexer provided by to obtain a reference to the plot, and then call on the plot reference.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates appending a subset of an array of y values with an increment of 1.0 seconds.
' Create random y data. Dim yData As Double() = New Double(49) {} Dim amp As Double = RandNumberGenerator.NextDouble() * 10 Dim increment As TimeSpan = TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1.0)
For i As Integer = 0 To yData.Length - 1 yData(i) = amp * Math.Sin(2 * i * Math.PI / yData.Length) + amp Next
' Set the X-Axis to display samples. wvfmGraph.XAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = timeFormatString ' Set the Y-Axis to display samples. wvfmGraph.YAxes(0).MajorDivisions.LabelFormat = samplesFormatString
If wvfmGraph.Plots(0).Mode <> WaveformPlotMode.PlotY Then wvfmGraph.ClearData() End If ' Plot yData starting at x value 4 with an increment of 1.0 ' seconds with the default precision mode wvfmGraph.PlotYAppend(yData, 0, yData.Length, increment, PlotDateTimePrecisionMode.[Default])

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.WaveformGraph.PlotLineColorGenerator
member.summary: Gets or sets the that assigns different colors to plots.
member.value: The that assigns different colors to plots. The default value is .
member.remarks:
At design time, when you add, delete, or move a plot up and down, the colors are reassigned according to the order in which they are specified in the color set. At run time, the color of the plot depends on its index in the plot collection when you add the plot to the collection. If you delete a plot at run time, the color of the other plots does not change.
When this property changes, the event is raised, and colors are assigned to all plots if is .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.UI.WindowsForms.WaveformGraph.UseColorGenerator
member.summary: Gets or sets whether is enabled or disabled.
member.value: to enable ; otherwise, . The default value is . At design time, this property is set to by a custom control designer for ease of use.
member.remarks: When this property is set to , plots are assigned different colors by the property; otherwise, the plots default to , unless you have explicitly set the colors. determines whether to draw the plot with auto-generated color or with a color you assign.
